channel.title: My Menoplan
channel.description: Science-based information to cope with menopause

item.title: Home
item.dc:creator: sblair
item.content:encoded:
[vc_row fullwidth="true"][vc_column][mk_edge_slider first_el="true" orderby="post__in" full_height="false" height="575" animation_effect="fade" animation_speed="1100" slideshow_speed="5500" direction_nav="slit" pagination="none" slides="439, 1345, 1353, 1355, 360"][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_color_style="gradient_color" thin_grandient_color_from="#75d8c0" thin_grandient_color_to="#28b590" thin_gradient_color_angle="horizontal" thickness="8" margin_top="0" margin_bottom="0"][/vc_column][/vc_row][mk_page_section bg_color="#ffffff" bg_position="right center" bottom_shape_style="curve-bottom" bottom_shape_size="small" bottom_shape_color="#f4f9f9" sidebar="sidebar-1"][vc_column][mk_padding_divider][vc_row_inner][vc_column_inner width="3/5"][mk_fancy_title strip_tags="true" color="#4f4b51" size="45" font_weight="300" margin_bottom="0" font_family="Raleway" font_type="google" el_class="eldwin marginbottom5"]What is Menopause?[/mk_fancy_title][vc_column_text css=".vc_custom_1630977803377{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]Menopause is when your period permanently stops.

For those who have a uterus, menopause usually happens naturally in their 40s or 50s. Perimenopause begins when they begin having symptoms and ends one year after their periods stop. After a whole year with no periods, the date of the final period is the date of the start of menopause. 

For those who had their uterus removed before their periods stopped, but kept their ovaries, menopause symptoms or bloods tests of hormones are used to tell when they are entering perimenopause. 

For others, menopause starts suddenly because of surgical removal of their ovaries, or when their ovaries quit making hormones because of radiation, or chemotherapy. Their date of menopause is the date when their ovaries are removed or they quit making hormones.

Learn more about perimenopause and menopause symptoms, and what you can do about them. See our guide for how to talk to your health care provider.

Use our tool to see what stage of perimenopause or menopause you are in.[/vc_column_text][mk_button_gradient dimension="flat" size="large" corner_style="full_rounded" grandient_color_from="#75d8c0" grandient_color_to="#28b590" grandient_color_angle="diagonal_left_bottom" grandient_color_fallback="#28b590" url="/about/" margin_top="10" margin_bottom="30" el_class="float-left-btn"]LEARN MORE[/mk_button_gradient][mk_button_gradient dimension="flat" size="large" corner_style="full_rounded" grandient_color_from="#75d8c0" grandient_color_to="#28b590" grandient_color_angle="diagonal_left_bottom" grandient_color_fallback="#28b590" url="/am-i-in-menopause/" margin_top="10" margin_bottom="30" el_class="float-left-btn"]FIND OUT IF I AM IN MENOPAUSE[/mk_button_gradient][/vc_column_inner][vc_column_inner width="2/5"][mk_padding_divider size="35" visibility="hidden-sm"][vc_single_image image="1394" img_size="full" alignment="center" el_class="infographic"][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_padding_divider size="30"][/vc_column][/mk_page_section][mk_page_section bg_color="#ecf3f3" bg_position="right center" top_shape_style="curve-top" top_shape_size="small" top_shape_bg_color="#f4f9f9" bottom_shape_style="curve-bottom" bottom_shape_size="small" bottom_shape_color="#ffffff" bottom_shape_bg_color="#f4f9f9" sidebar="sidebar-1"][vc_column][mk_padding_divider size="30"][vc_row_inner column_padding="5"][vc_column_inner width="1/2"][vc_column_text css=".vc_custom_1593620284907{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"][/vc_column_text][mk_padding_divider][vc_single_image image="703" img_size="full" alignment="center"][/vc_column_inner][vc_column_inner el_class="padding-fix-homepage" width="1/2"][mk_padding_divider size="16"][mk_fancy_title strip_tags="true" color="#4f4b51" size="45" font_weight="300" margin_top="10" margin_bottom="0" font_family="Raleway" font_type="google" el_class="eldwin marginbottom5"]Who We Are[/mk_fancy_title][vc_column_text css=".vc_custom_1592409955339{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]We are menopause scientists and women’s health care doctors from across the United States. We have been working together for over 25 years to find out what works and what doesn’t. We are committed to sharing what we have learned with women everywhere.[/vc_column_text][mk_button_gradient dimension="flat" size="large" corner_style="full_rounded" grandient_color_from="#75d8c0" grandient_color_to="#28b590" grandient_color_angle="diagonal_left_bottom" grandient_color_fallback="#28b590" url="http://mymenoplan.org/our-team/" margin_top="10"]MEET OUR TEAM[/mk_button_gradient][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][/vc_column][/mk_page_section][mk_page_section bg_color="#ffffff" bg_position="right center" bottom_shape_style="curve-bottom" bottom_shape_size="small" bottom_shape_color="#ffffff" bottom_shape_bg_color="#fcfcfc" sidebar="sidebar-1"][vc_column][mk_padding_divider size="30"][vc_row_inner][vc_column_inner width="2/3"][mk_padding_divider size="30"][mk_fancy_title strip_tags="true" color="#4f4b51" size="45" font_weight="300" margin_bottom="10" font_family="Raleway" font_type="google" el_class="eldwin marginbottom5"]Create Your Menoplan[/mk_fancy_title][vc_column_text css=".vc_custom_1611959241658{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]Tell us your symptoms, and our online tool gives you options for dealing with them.

The tool can help you sort out the best options, given your preferences. Do you want to take medications or avoid them? Did you have a natural menopause? Do you want to avoid treatments that are riskier? Personalize your options. Then start trying things you can do on your own or talk with your doctor.[/vc_column_text][mk_button_gradient dimension="flat" size="large" corner_style="full_rounded" grandient_color_from="#75d8c0" grandient_color_to="#28b590" grandient_color_angle="diagonal_left_bottom" grandient_color_fallback="#28b590" url="http://mymenoplan.org/create-my-menoplan/" margin_top="10"]START CREATING YOUR MENOPLAN[/mk_button_gradient][/vc_column_inner][vc_column_inner width="1/3"][vc_single_image image="1775" img_size="full" alignment="center" onclick="custom_link" link="http://mymenoplan.org/create-my-menoplan/"][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][/vc_column][/mk_page_section][mk_page_section bg_color="#ecf3f3" bg_position="right center" top_shape_style="curve-top" top_shape_size="small" top_shape_color="#ffffff" top_shape_bg_color="#f4f9f9" bottom_shape_style="curve-bottom" bottom_shape_size="small" bottom_shape_color="#ffffff" bottom_shape_bg_color="#f4f9f9" sidebar="sidebar-1"][vc_column][vc_row_inner attached="true" column_padding="30"][vc_column_inner width="2/3" css=".vc_custom_1627685033465{margin-right: 25px !important;}"][mk_padding_divider size="30"][mk_blockquote font_family="none" el_class="quote"]It hit me a lot harder than I could have ever imagined. Seeing that other women have made it and they're okay - it's very inspiring and gives you hope.
- Amy, Texas[/mk_blockquote][mk_blockquote font_family="none" el_class="quote"]I started getting hot flashes, really horrible, horrible hot flashes. Like I thought I would spontaneously combust sitting in a chair.
- Darlene, Tennessee[/mk_blockquote][mk_blockquote font_family="none" el_class="quote"]This baby here was a surprise. I'm 47. She's the change-of-life baby. You still can get pregnant until you are finished with the menopause transition.
- Kourtnee, South Carolina[/mk_blockquote][/vc_column_inner][vc_column_inner width="1/3"][mk_padding_divider][mk_fancy_title strip_tags="true" color="#4f4b51" size="45" font_weight="300" margin_bottom="10" font_family="Raleway" font_type="google" el_class="eldwin marginbottom5"]Meno Stories[/mk_fancy_title][vc_column_text css=".vc_custom_1627685136114{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]Real women sharing their experiences and feelings about perimenopause and menopause.[/vc_column_text][mk_button_gradient dimension="flat" size="large" corner_style="full_rounded" grandient_color_from="#75d8c0" grandient_color_to="#28b590" grandient_color_angle="diagonal_left_bottom" grandient_color_fallback="#28b590" url="http://mymenoplan.org/womens-stories/" margin_top="10"]READ MORE[/mk_button_gradient][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_padding_divider size="30"][mk_padding_divider size="90"][/vc_column][/mk_page_section]

[mk_page_section vertical_align="top" bg_image="http://mymenoplan.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/butterfly1a-scaled.jpg" bg_position="left center" bg_stretch="true" sidebar="sidebar-1"][vc_column][mk_fancy_title color="#ffffff" size="56" font_weight="100" margin_top="100" margin_bottom="100" font_family="none" align="center" el_class="eldwin pagetitle"]About[/mk_fancy_title][/vc_column][/mk_page_section][vc_row fullwidth="true"][vc_column][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_color_style="gradient_color" thin_grandient_color_from="#75d8c0" thin_grandient_color_to="#28b590" thin_gradient_color_angle="horizontal" thickness="4" margin_top="0" margin_bottom="0"][/vc_column][/vc_row][vc_row][vc_column][mk_padding_divider size="80"][mk_fancy_title strip_tags="true" style="true" color="#4f4b51" size="25" font_weight="400" margin_bottom="0" font_family="none" align="center"]About Menopause[/mk_fancy_title][mk_padding_divider size="25"][vc_column_text css=".vc_custom_1593027163119{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]Menopause can be freeing. Freedom from periods, pregnancy concerns, and birth control. Once we are postmenopausal, most of us find that our moods and emotions settle down. Our sex lives may improve when we're not worrying about pregnancy. Let us help you deal with the symptoms of menopause and perimenopause, so you can better enjoy the new you.[/vc_column_text][mk_padding_divider size="25"][vc_row_inner][vc_column_inner width="1/3"][vc_single_image image="480" img_size="300x200" alignment="center" onclick="custom_link" link="/questions-and-answers/" el_class="rounded-corners"][mk_fancy_title strip_tags="true" size="16" font_weight="bold" font_style="normal" txt_transform="uppercase" margin_top="-20" margin_bottom="0" font_family="none" align="center" el_class="landing-title-links"]

item.title: Questions and Answers
item.dc:creator: sblair
item.content:encoded:
[mk_page_section vertical_align="top" bg_image="http://mymenoplan.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/int-q-as-scaled.jpg" bg_position="left center" bg_stretch="true" sidebar="sidebar-1"][vc_column][mk_fancy_title color="#ffffff" size="56" font_weight="100" margin_top="100" margin_bottom="100" font_family="none" align="center" el_class="eldwin pagetitle"]About[/mk_fancy_title][/vc_column][/mk_page_section][vc_row fullwidth="true"][vc_column][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_color_style="gradient_color" thin_grandient_color_from="#75d8c0" thin_grandient_color_to="#28b590" thin_gradient_color_angle="horizontal" thickness="4" margin_top="0" margin_bottom="0"][mk_padding_divider size="20"][vc_single_image image="2054" img_size="400 x 200" alignment="center" style="vc_box_shadow"][/vc_column][/vc_row][vc_row][vc_column][mk_fancy_title strip_tags="true" style="true" color="#4f4b51" size="25" font_weight="400" letter_spacing="1" margin_bottom="0" font_family="none" align="center"]QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS[/mk_fancy_title][mk_padding_divider size="20"][/vc_column][/vc_row][vc_row][vc_column width="2/3"][vc_column_text css=".vc_custom_1633209161610{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]

What is Perimenopause? Perimenopause begins when the time from one period to the next varies by at least 7 days. It extends through menopause (the last menstrual period) to 1 year after menopause. Perimenopause nearly always happens with natural menopause, not induced menopause

What is the Menopause transition? The span of time from when periods begin changing to the date of the final menstrual period.

What is menopause?  Menopause is when your periods permanently stop. If you have your uterus and ovaries you are menopausal when you have 12 months in a row without a period. Natural menopause happens because of changes in the ovaries. As you age, the number of eggs in the ovaries decreases. Gradually the ovaries quit making the hormones that prepare your body for pregnancy. The date of your final menstrual period is your date of menopause. If you have both your ovaries removed before your periods have stopped your date of surgery is your date of menopause, and you are postmenopausal.[/vc_column_text][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][mk_toggle title="What are the different types of menopause?"]Natural menopause: This is the term used for menopause that happens at age 40 and above, and is not due to removal of both ovaries, medications or radiation. The body is going through the normal reproductive changes of aging.

Early menopause/premature menopause: Menopause that happens earlier than the normal range of menopause. Menopause that happens before age 40. It may be the result of genetics, autoimmune disorders, medical procedures, surgery, or medical treatments.

Primary ovarian insufficiency (POI). Sometimes called premature ovarian failure, this condition that happens at age less than 40 when many periods in a row are skipped or there are no periods at all. This can be a sign of menopause or of very few eggs left in the ovaries. POI differs from premature menopause because ovarian activity may start again.

Surgical menopause: Menopause that happens when both ovaries are surgically removed before a woman has reached a natural menopause. Surgery will cause menopause suddenly, and as a result, the symptoms may be more severe.

Induced menopause: Menopause that happens earlier than expected when both ovaries are surgically removed or permanently damaged by cancer treatments (pelvic radiation or chemotherapy) before a woman has reach a natural menopause.[/mk_toggle][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][mk_toggle title="What's the timeline - from perimenopause to postmenopause?"]Premenopause: The time from puberty (onset of menstrual periods) to perimenopause.

Menopause transition: The span of time from when periods begin changing to the date of the final menstrual period.

Perimenopause: Perimenopause begins when the time from one period to the next varies by at least 7 days. It extends through menopause (the last menstrual period) to 1 year after menopause. Perimenopause nearly always happens with natural menopause, not induced menopause.

Menopause: The final menstrual period, which can be confirmed after 12 months in a row without a period. This time marks the end of menstruation and fertility. It is a normal, natural event associated with reduced functioning of the ovaries, resulting in lower levels of ovarian hormones (primarily estradiol).

Late menopause: A vague term used to indicate menopause that occurs later in the normal range of menopause.

Postmenopause: The span of time after menopause (the final menstrual period).

  • NOTE: This Timeline can shift due to certain surgery, medications, or radiation.

[/mk_toggle][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][mk_toggle title="When does menopause happen?"]The median age of natural menopause (last menstrual period) is 50-52 years. The median age of perimenopause is 47.5 years. Median means half are above and half are below.[/mk_toggle][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][mk_toggle title="Why does menopause happen?"]Natural menopause happens because the ovaries gradually stop making estradiol. As estradiol production decreases women enter perimenopause.

Other causes of menopause include surgical removal of the ovaries, or drugs like chemotherapy that damage the ovaries.[/mk_toggle][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][mk_toggle title="What affects how old you are when your periods stop? (Age at menopause)"]Earlier menopause can happen with:

  • Smoking (0.8-1.7 yrs earlier)
  • Living at very high altitude (Andes, Himalayas)
  • Hysterectomy  - even if the ovaries are not removed.
  • Lower income and education levels (probably due to other health conditions)
  • Shorter menstrual cycle length


Later menopause can happen with:

  • Use of oral contraceptives
  • More months of breast feeding
  • Higher number of pregnancies

[/mk_toggle][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][mk_toggle title="What about women who had a hysterectomy but kept their ovaries?"]In this case, one way to tell a woman is becoming perimenopausal is when they start having symptoms such as hot flashes or trouble sleeping. Their health care provider can do blood tests to check their hormones and see if they are perimenopausal or postmenopausal.[/mk_toggle][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][mk_toggle title="What are common symptoms and treatments?"]Read more about symptoms.

Read more about treatments.[/mk_toggle][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][mk_toggle title="How long do hot flashes and night sweats last?"]The median length of time women have hot flashes and night sweats is 7.4 years (median means right in the middle - for half of women it is longer and for half it is shorter).

How long hot flashes and night sweats occur varies depending on race/ethnicity:

  • Non-Hispanic white women (6.5 years)
  • Hispanic/Latino women (8.9 years)
  • African American Women (10.1 years)
  • Japanese women (4.8 years)
  • Chinese women (5.4 years)

The duration is longest in women who begin having hot flashes or night sweats when they are pre or peri menopausal (11.8 years).

The duration is shortest in women who begin having hot flashes or night sweats after their periods have stopped. (3.4 years)

The duration is longer in those with younger age at 1st experience of hot flashes/night sweats, ever smokers, women with a greater BMI, women with higher symptom sensitivity, anxiety, perceived stress, and depressive symptoms.

The duration is shorter in women who are married or partnered, women with higher educational level and less financial strain, and those with greater social support.

The median duration of symptoms after the final menstrual period is 4.5 years.[/mk_toggle][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][mk_toggle title="What about hormone testing to see if I’m in the menopause transition?"]You may wonder if you can have your hormone levels tested to see if you are in the menopause transition or postmenopausal. Usually this isn’t necessary- or even helpful - for most women. That’s because hormone levels go up and down during your menstrual cycle and can have large and irregular swings during the menopause transition.

For most women, the best way to know if you are perimenopausal or in the menopause transition is to notice changes in your periods and whether you have menopause symptoms. Our tool, Am I In Menopause? , can tell you your menopause stage.

Hormone testing can help some women.

  • If your periods stop when you are unusually young (under age 40), your health care provider may test your hormones to see what is happening.
  • If you had a hysterectomy before your periods stopped or are using hormonal contraceptives that cause your period to stop (like the progesterone IUD), you may get your hormones tested to see if you are in the menopause transition.
  • If you are over 50 years and are taking combined hormonal contraceptives and are still having periods, you may get your hormones tested when you are on the last day of your placebo pills week (week 4 in a pill pack). Combined hormonal contraceptives can hide the symptoms of menopause.

If your health care provider thinks you need a hormone test, a small blood sample will be drawn. Usually your FSH (follicle stimulating hormone) level will be measured. The test is often done twice, at least 4 weeks apart. Your estradiol level may also be tested. An FSH higher than 30 mIu/ml with estradiol less than 50 pg/mL is a good sign that you are perimenopausal or have reached menopause.[/mk_toggle][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][mk_toggle title="Does smoking affect the menopause transition?"]You may wonder, what does smoking have to do with menopause? Women who smoke cigarettes are more likely to have hot flashes, to have more of them and to have more severe hot flashes during menopause. They also tend to begin the menopause transition at an earlier age. Unfortunately, the menopause transition is usually longer in women the transition at an earlier age. Never smoking is even better. Non-smokers have the fewest and least severe hot flashes

Other forms of nicotine, such as vaping, have not been studied for their effect on menopause symptoms. Nor is there good quality research on the effects of marijuana, THC, or CBD oil, despite some of the current hype about CBD oil.

The positive effects of quitting smoking on hot flashes and night sweats don’t happen until 5 years after quitting. However, quitting smoking before menopause is associated with fewer hot flashes and less severe hot flashes. The earlier you quit before menopause the greater the impact.

There are lots of reasons to quit smoking. Add hot flashes to the list.

If you want to quit smoking there are great free resources to help you quit. Two of our favorites are:

  • https://women.smokefree.gov/ by the U.S. National Institutes of Health, and
  • https://www.becomeanex.org/   by the non-profit Legacy Foundation.

[/mk_toggle][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][mk_toggle title="References"]

  • Avid NS, Crawford SL, Greendale G et al. Duration of menopausal vasomotor symptoms over the menopause transitions. JAMA Intern Med Feb 16, 2016.
  • Harlow SD, Gass M, Hall JE, Lobo R, Maki P, Rebar RW, Sherman S, Sluss PM, de Villiers TJ; STRAW + 10 Collaborative Group. Executive summary of the Stages of Reproductive Aging Workshop + 10: addressing the unfinished agenda of staging reproductive aging. J Clin Endocrinol Metab. 2012 Apr;97(4):1159-68. doi: 10.1210/jc.2011-3362. Epub 2012 Feb 16. PMID: 22344196; PMCID: PMC3319184.
  • http://www.menopause.org/for-women/menopause-glossary North American Menopause Society, Menopause Glossary, Accessed May 6, 2019
  • Midgette AS, Baron JA. Cigarette smoking and the risk of natural menopause. Epidemiology 1990;1:474-480. (review article)
  • Smith RL, Flaws JA, Gallicchi L. Does quitting smoking decrease the risk of midlife hot flashes? A longitudinal analysis. Maturitas.82(1): 123–127. doi:10.1016/j.maturitas.2015.06.029.
  • Treloar AE, Boynton RE, Behn BG, et al. Variation of the human menstrual cycle through reproductive life. Int J Fertil. 1966; 12(Pt 2):77–126. [PubMed: 5419031]
  • Zhu D, Chung H-F, Pandeya N, Dobson, AJ, Cade JE, Greenwood DC, et al. Relationships between intensity, duration, cumulative dose, and timing of smoking with age at menopause: A pooled analysis of individual data from 17 observational studies. PLoS Med 2018;15(11): https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pmed.1002704

item.title: Strategies to Talk with Your Doctor
item.dc:creator: sblair
item.content:encoded:
[mk_page_section vertical_align="top" bg_image="http://mymenoplan.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/int-talk-doctor-scaled.jpg" bg_position="left center" bg_stretch="true" sidebar="sidebar-1"][vc_column][mk_fancy_title color="#ffffff" size="56" font_weight="100" margin_top="100" margin_bottom="100" font_family="none" align="center" el_class="eldwin pagetitle"]About[/mk_fancy_title][/vc_column][/mk_page_section][vc_row fullwidth="true"][vc_column][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_color_style="gradient_color" thin_grandient_color_from="#75d8c0" thin_grandient_color_to="#28b590" thin_gradient_color_angle="horizontal" thickness="4" margin_top="0" margin_bottom="0"][/vc_column][/vc_row][vc_row][vc_column][mk_padding_divider size="80"][mk_fancy_title strip_tags="true" style="true" color="#4f4b51" size="25" font_weight="400" letter_spacing="1" margin_bottom="0" font_family="none" align="center"]STRATEGIES FOR TALKING WITH YOUR DOCTOR[/mk_fancy_title][mk_padding_divider size="20"][/vc_column][/vc_row][vc_row][vc_column width="2/3"][vc_column_text disable_pattern="false" el_class="numbered-list" css=".vc_custom_1626204646902{margin-bottom: 0px !important;margin-left: 0px !important;}"]These strategies can help you get answers to your most important questions when you talk to your doctor about menopause.  

  1. Pick a doctor who will listen to your concerns and honor your preferences.  
  2. Be prepared. Set your agenda for the visit. Write down your menopause symptoms and list of questions with the most important ones first. 
  3. Share your symptom and question list at the beginning of the visit.   Your doctor may see something that is low on your list that they think is important.
  4. Use the My Menoplan tool and print it. Show it to your doctor to guide the discussion.  
  5. Be clear about your goal for the visit. For example – “I came today because I’m having hot flashes that are keeping me awake all night. I want to talk about my options.”
  6. Bring along a friend or family member who can help you re-visit what was said. 
  7. Take notes or ask the person with you to take notes. 
  8. If the conversation is going to be complex, ask to record it. Most smart phones have a record option. This is a great way to be sure you get all the information. It may surprise your doctor, but they should be open to this. 
  9. Repeat back what you heard – “OK, so you are saying hormones are not a good idea for me”. 
  10. Ask for a written after-visit summary.
  11. Find out how you can see your medical record in the patient portal. The record has your test results, diagnoses, treatment plans, summaries of your visits and medications. 
  12. If your questions aren’t answered in one visit, schedule another – or: 
  13. Keep the conversation going. Email your questions or let your doctor know your progress using the patient portal.  For example - "I've on been on this medication for three weeks and I don't see a change".  

[/vc_column_text][/vc_column][vc_column width="1/3"][vc_wp_custommenu title="About Menopause" nav_menu="20"][mk_fancy_title strip_tags="true" color="#28b590" size="18" font_weight="400" margin_bottom="0" font_family="none" align="center"]CREATE MY MENOPLAN[/mk_fancy_title][vc_single_image image="1775" img_size="full" onclick="custom_link" link="http://mymenoplan.org/create-my-menoplan/"][/vc_column][/vc_row][vc_row][vc_column][mk_padding_divider size="100"][/vc_column][/vc_row]

item.title: What If I Have Breast Cancer
item.dc:creator: sblair
item.content:encoded:
[mk_page_section vertical_align="top" bg_image="http://mymenoplan.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/int-bc-scaled.jpg" bg_position="left center" bg_stretch="true" sidebar="sidebar-1"][vc_column][mk_fancy_title color="#ffffff" size="56" font_weight="100" margin_top="100" margin_bottom="100" font_family="none" align="center" el_class="eldwin pagetitle"]About[/mk_fancy_title][/vc_column][/mk_page_section][vc_row fullwidth="true"][vc_column][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_color_style="gradient_color" thin_grandient_color_from="#75d8c0" thin_grandient_color_to="#28b590" thin_gradient_color_angle="horizontal" thickness="4" margin_top="0" margin_bottom="0"][/vc_column][/vc_row][vc_row][vc_column][mk_padding_divider size="80"][mk_fancy_title strip_tags="true" style="true" color="#4f4b51" size="25" font_weight="400" letter_spacing="1" margin_bottom="0" font_family="none" align="center"]WHAT IF I HAVE BREAST CANCER?[/mk_fancy_title][mk_padding_divider size="20"][/vc_column][/vc_row][vc_row][vc_column width="2/3"][vc_column_text disable_pattern="false" css=".vc_custom_1627332415164{margin-bottom: 0px !important;margin-left: 0px !important;}"]What are my options if I have or have had breast cancer?
If you have breast cancer now or are a breast cancer survivor, you may have more intense menopause symptoms than your friends without breast cancer.

Estrogen-containing medicines that might help with your menopause symptoms are not usually recommended for women who have had breast cancer.   The MyMenoPlan Tool  can help you avoid risky treatments. We also have more detailed information below. Feel free to share it with your doctors.

Hot Flashes
About two-thirds of breast cancer survivors have hot flashes. Many things can cause these hot flashes. Some cancer treatments quickly stop the ovaries from making hormones. This can cause a sudden and intense menopause. And some of the drugs used long-term after breast cancer can cause hot flashes. Hot flashes tend to be worse during chemotherapy or when starting tamoxifen, aromatize inhibitors, or drugs that shut down your ovaries temporarily (e.g. Lupron). Hot flashes then stabilize or decrease slightly over time and depending on your cancer treatments and your age, the ovaries may resume normal function.

Physical changes, emotional changes, and intimacy
Breast cancer treatments can cause physical and emotional changes. In turn, those changes can affect your body image, feelings of intimacy, and sex life. Some women worry about how their body looks and are concerned about how their partner sees them. Other women stop desiring sex. During sex, some women feel their vagina is dry or sore, or they find it’s hard to have an orgasm. Even women who don’t have sex can feel discomfort from vaginal dryness and atrophy. Vaginal atrophy is a thinning and drying of vaginal walls.

Treatment options for breast cancer patients or survivors
The sections below point you to safe ways to deal with hot flashes and vaginal symptoms. Since hormonal treatments increase the risk of breast cancer recurrence, they are usually avoided (except for low doses of vaginal estrogen). Hormonal treatments that usually are not recommended are estrogen or progesterone pills, patches or gels.

Improving hot flashes
You can try the following treatments on your own or with a specialist. They do not require prescriptions. Some have been shown to work. Others may help and won’t hurt you. We also let you know which treatments don’t seem to work. As always, every woman is unique, so treatments that help some women may not work for you.

  • Cooling techniques: The easiest things to try aren’t really treatments. They are ways to make yourself more comfortable during a hot flash. Our section on cooling techniques has lots of suggestions.  You can also ask your friends and family what their favorite cooling techniques were. Try some yourself and see what helps.
  • Hypnosis: Hypnosis decreases how often women with breast cancer get hot flashes and how bad they feel.
  • Acupuncture: It may be worth trying acupuncture. Some studies show that the number of hot flashes decrease when treated one to two times per week for up to 12 weeks. Other studies show no effect of acupuncture. However, the studies are mostly of poor quality, so it is not clear what the effect really is. The main side effects of acupuncture are mild pain and bruising from needles.
  • Yoga: Yoga may decrease the number of hot flashes in women after breast cancer.
  • Mindfulness based practices: Mindfulness based practices generally do not decrease hot flashes for women with breast cancer.

Several hormone-free medicines decrease hot flashes and are safe in breast cancer survivors. The treatments help whether or not you are taking tamoxifen or aromatase inhibitors. They can be prescribed by your healthcare provider.

  • Venlafaxine (Effexor, 75 mg per day), citalopram (Celexa, 10, 20 or 30 mg per day), paroxetine (Paxil, Brisdelle, 10 mg per day), duloxetine (Irenka, Cymbalta, 60 mg per day), escitalopram (Lexapro 10, 20 or 30 mg), and desvenlafaxine (Pristiq, 25, 50, 100 mg) reduced the frequency and severity of hot flashes by 50% after 4-6 weeks of therapy. You can read more about these drugs here. Common side effects are nausea, dizziness, and dry mouth. A note of caution is important for two of these drugs: paroxetine and duloxetine. It has not been proved, but they might affect how well tamoxifen works.
  • Clonidine (0.1 mg daily) patch reduced hot flash frequency and severity by 50% after 4-6 weeks of use. The most common side effects of clonidine are dry mouth and constipation.
  • Gabapentin (900 mg per day) or pregabalin (15 mg per day) reduced hot flash frequency and severity by 50% after 4-6 weeks.

      The following treatments have not improved hot flashes in breast cancer survivors. They have been studied using the “gold standard” of research methods -  in randomized controlled trials. The treatments that do not affect hot flashes are: black cohosh, aerobic exercise, soy and phytoestrogens, vitamin E, fluoxetine, sertraline and bupropion.

Improving vaginal health / sexual health

You may experience problems such as vaginal dryness, pain during sex, or low sex drive. The solutions for breast cancer patients and survivors are the same as for other women. Before trying vaginal estrogen consider trying vaginal lubricants or moisturizers.

You can read more about each of these symptoms:

  • Pain with sex
  • Vaginal pain or dryness not during sex
  • Low sex drive

and potential treatments and coping strategies:

  • Vaginal estrogen
  • Vaginal lubricants and moisturizers
  • Vaginal laser therapy
  • Vaginal dilators
  • Vaginal physical therapy

If your cancer diagnosis or treatments are affecting your sex life you also might consider seeing a therapist yourself or with your partner.

No consistent improvements in sexual health were seen with physical activity, transdermal testosterone, vaginal testosterone, or anti-depressants.

No published studies in breast cancer survivors were found on: DHEA (dehydroepiandrosterone), vaginal dilators, vaginal physical therapy, pelvic floor exercises, ospemifene or flibanserin.

 

 


REFERENCES
Barton DL, LaVasseur BI, Sloan JA, et al. Phase III, placebo-controlled trial of three doses of citalopram for the treatment of hot flashes: NCCTG trial N05C9. J Clin Oncol. 2010;28(20):3278‐3283. doi:10.1200/JCO.2009.26.6379

Barton DL, Loprinzi CL, Quella SK, et al. Prospective evaluation of vitamin E for hot flashes in breast cancer survivors. J Clin Oncol. 1998;16(2):495‐500. doi:10.1200/JCO.1998.16.2.495

Boekhout AH, Vincent AD, Dalesio OB, et al. Management of hot flashes in patients who have breast cancer with venlafaxine and clonidine: a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial. J Clin Oncol. 2011;29(29):3862‐3868. doi:10.1200/JCO.2010.33.1298

Bokmand S, Flyger H. Acupuncture relieves menopausal discomfort in breast cancer patients: a prospective, double blinded, randomized study. Breast. 2013;22(3):320‐323. doi:10.1016/j.breast.2012.07.015

Bordeleau L, Pritchard KI, Loprinzi CL, et al. Multicenter, randomized, cross-over clinical trial of venlafaxine versus gabapentin for the management of hot flashes in breast cancer survivors. J Clin Oncol. 2010;28(35):5147‐5152. doi:10.1200/JCO.2010.29.9230

Carson JW, Carson KM, Porter LS, Keefe FJ, Seewaldt VL. Yoga of Awareness program for menopausal symptoms in breast cancer survivors: results from a randomized trial. Support Care Cancer. 2009;17(10):1301‐1309. doi:10.1007/s00520-009-0587-5

Cramer H, Rabsilber S, Lauche R, Kümmel S, Dobos G. Yoga and meditation for menopausal symptoms in breast cancer survivors-A randomized controlled trial. Cancer. 2015;121(13):2175‐2184. doi:10.1002/cncr.29330

item.title: Our Story
item.dc:creator: sblair
item.content:encoded:
[mk_page_section vertical_align="top" bg_image="http://mymenoplan.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/butterfly1a-scaled.jpg" bg_position="left center" bg_stretch="true" sidebar="sidebar-1"][vc_column][mk_fancy_title color="#ffffff" size="56" font_weight="100" margin_top="100" margin_bottom="100" font_family="none" align="center" el_class="eldwin pagetitle"]Who We Are[/mk_fancy_title][/vc_column][/mk_page_section][vc_row fullwidth="true"][vc_column][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_color_style="gradient_color" thin_grandient_color_from="#75d8c0" thin_grandient_color_to="#28b590" thin_gradient_color_angle="horizontal" thickness="4" margin_top="0" margin_bottom="0"][/vc_column][/vc_row][vc_row][vc_column][mk_padding_divider size="80"][mk_fancy_title strip_tags="true" style="true" color="#4f4b51" size="25" font_weight="400" margin_bottom="0" font_family="none" align="center"]OUR STORY[/mk_fancy_title][mk_padding_divider size="25"][/vc_column][/vc_row][vc_row][vc_column width="2/3"][vc_column_text css=".vc_custom_1611959104446{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]Why are we doing this? We want women to have a place to go to get accurate, up-to-date, unbiased and personalized information about what works and what doesn’t work. We want to empower women to make decisions about menopause that work for them.

Who are we? We are doctors and university-based menopause scientists. We formed a nationwide research network and have worked together for over 25 years.

Why should you trust us? Our funding comes from US tax dollars through the National Institutes of Health, not from private companies like drug or supplement manufacturers. We are not trying to sell you anything. We don’t think one solution works best for everyone. We care passionately about women. Our careers have been dedicated to women’s health and wellbeing.

Development of this website was funded by a grant from the National Institute of Aging,  #R01AG048209.[/vc_column_text][/vc_column][vc_column width="1/3"][vc_wp_custommenu title="Who We Are" nav_menu="21"][mk_fancy_title strip_tags="true" color="#28b590" size="18" font_weight="400" margin_bottom="0" font_family="none" align="center"]CREATE MY MENOPLAN[/mk_fancy_title][vc_single_image image="1775" img_size="full" alignment="center" onclick="custom_link" link="http://mymenoplan.org/create-my-menoplan/"][/vc_column][/vc_row][vc_row][vc_column][mk_padding_divider size="100"][/vc_column][/vc_row]

item.title: Hot Flashes & Night Sweats
item.dc:creator: sblair
item.content:encoded:
[mk_page_section vertical_align="top" bg_image="http://mymenoplan.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/int-q-as-scaled.jpg" bg_position="left center" bg_stretch="true" sidebar="sidebar-1"][vc_column][mk_fancy_title color="#ffffff" size="56" font_weight="100" margin_top="100" margin_bottom="100" font_family="none" align="center" el_class="eldwin pagetitle"]Symptoms[/mk_fancy_title][/vc_column][/mk_page_section][vc_row fullwidth="true"][vc_column][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_color_style="gradient_color" thin_grandient_color_from="#75d8c0" thin_grandient_color_to="#28b590" thin_gradient_color_angle="horizontal" thickness="4" margin_top="0" margin_bottom="0"][/vc_column][/vc_row][vc_row][vc_column][mk_padding_divider size="20"][mk_fancy_title strip_tags="true" style="true" color="#4f4b51" size="25" font_weight="400" letter_spacing="1" margin_bottom="0" font_family="none" align="center"]HOT FLASHES & NIGHT SWEATS[/mk_fancy_title][mk_padding_divider size="20"][vc_row_inner][vc_column_inner width="2/3"][vc_column_text disable_pattern="false" css=".vc_custom_1620064453344{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]
  • What is it
  • What's happening to my body
  • What to expect
  • Track my hot flashes  (download PDF) [icon name="PDF File (regular)" class="" unprefixed_class=""]
  • Treatments that help
  • Treatments that may help
  • Treatments that do not help
  • References
[/vc_column_text][/vc_column_inner][vc_column_inner width="1/3"][vc_single_image image="792" img_size="180 x 180" alignment="center"][vc_raw_html][/vc_raw_html][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][/vc_column][/vc_row][vc_row][vc_column width="2/3"][vc_row_inner el_id="what-flash"][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][vc_column_text css=".vc_custom_1621445584376{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]WHAT IS IT? A hot flash (night sweat when it happens at night) is a sudden feeling of warmth that often appears to occur without reason. It is most often felt in the torso, neck and face. There may be sweating, flushing or redness in the face, neck, and chest, palpitations, and feelings of anxiety. A hot flash usually lasts about 2-10 minutes. It may be followed by a feeling of chilliness. Intensity varies from a feeling of mild warmth to intense heat.[/vc_column_text][vc_row_inner el_id="happen-flash"][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][vc_column_text disable_pattern="false" css=".vc_custom_1621445636141{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]WHAT'S HAPPENING TO MY BODY? While hot flashes and night sweats have many causes, the most common cause in mid-life women is entering the menopause transition. During the transition, the hypothalamus (a part of the brain that controls temperature and other functions) appears to mistake small increases in body temperature as a signal that a woman is too warm. It then sends signals to help the woman cool down. Blood vessels near the skin dilate to help the body give off heat. Sweating is another cooling mechanism.[/vc_column_text][vc_row_inner el_id="expect-flash"][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][vc_column_text disable_pattern="false" css=".vc_custom_1626204488348{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]WHAT TO EXPECT Up to 80% of women have hot flashes and/or night sweats during the menopause transition and postmenopause. About 30-50% of these women say they are frequent or severe. There seem to be four general patterns.
  • Symptoms start early in the menopause transition and stop at menopause (when periods stop completely).
  • Symptoms start later in the menopause transition but continue in the postmenopause.
  • Very mild or no symptoms.
  • Symptoms start long before the last menstrual period and continue long into the postmenopausal period.
How long do hot flashes last? A large U.S. study followed women through the menopause transition and postmenopause. In that study, the median total duration of frequent or moderate to severe hot flashes/night sweats was 7.4 years (this means that for half of women hot flashes lasted less than 7.4 years and for half they lasted longer than 7.4 years). The median duration after the last menstrual period was 4.5 years. For women who were premenopausal or in the early perimenopause when they started having hot flashes, the median was greater than 11.8 years and they continued for a median of 9.4 years after the last menstrual period. The median duration varies by race/ethnicity. The longest duration is in African-American women (10.9 years) followed by Japanese women (9.4 years), non-Hispanic white women (0.1 years), Chinese women (5.5 years) and Hispanic women (9.4 years).[/vc_column_text][vc_row_inner el_id="help-flash"][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][mk_icon_box icon="mk-icon-check" title="RESEARCH SHOWS THESE TREATMENT HELP" text_size="17" font_weight="bold" icon_size="medium" margin="0"]
  • Hormone therapy: estrogen pills, patches, and creams
  • Some antidepressant medications
  • Hypnosis
  • Gabapentin
  • Clonidine
[/mk_icon_box][vc_row_inner el_id="may-help-flash"][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][mk_icon_box icon="mk-icon-circle-o" title="THESE TREATMENTS MAY HELP, BUT WE NEED MORE RESEARCH" text_size="17" font_weight="bold" icon_size="medium" icon_color="#d3bb72" margin="10"]
  • Cognitive behavioral therapy
  • Cooling techniques 
  • Avoiding Triggers
  • Equol Supplement 
  • Yoga 
  • Weight Loss 
[/mk_icon_box][vc_row_inner el_id="not-help-flash"][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][mk_icon_box icon="mk-icon-ban" title="RESEARCH SHOWS THESE TREATMENTS DO NOT HELP" text_size="17" font_weight="bold" icon_size="medium" icon_color="#dd3333" margin="10"]
  • Dietary Soy
  • Phytoestrogen Supplements
  • Paced respiration
  • Herbal Remedies 
  • Omega 3 Supplements
  • Acupuncture
[/mk_icon_box][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][vc_column_text css=".vc_custom_1617136206778{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"][icon name="asterisk" class="" unprefixed_class=""]  Treatments that are inappropriate or have not been studied for this symptom are not listed.[/vc_column_text][vc_row_inner el_id="references-flash"][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_top="10" margin_bottom="10"][mk_toggle title="REFERENCES"]Avis NE, Crawford SL, Greendale G, Bromberger JT, Everson-Rose SA, Gold EB, Hess R, Joffe H, Kravitz HM, Tepper PG, Thurston RC. Duration of menopausal vasomotor symptoms over the menopause transition. JAMA Intern Med. 2015 Apr;175(4):531-9. doi:10.1001/jamainternmed.2014.8063. PMID: 25686030. Thurston RC.  Vasomotor symptoms: natural history, physiology, and links with cardiovascular health. Climacteric. 2018 Apr;21(2):96-100. doi:10.1080/13697137.2018.1430131. PMID: 29390899.[/mk_toggle][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][vc_column_text css=".vc_custom_1617118835964{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]Authors: Dr. Katherine Newton & Dr. Leslie Snyder.  Last reviewed: April, 2021[/vc_column_text][vc_row_inner][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][/vc_column][vc_column width="1/3" css=".vc_custom_1594159466278{background-position: center !important;background-repeat: no-repeat !important;background-size: cover !important;}"][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][vc_row_inner][vc_column_inner][mk_fancy_title strip_tags="true" color="#404040" size="20" font_weight="400" margin_bottom="0" font_family="none" align="center"]CREATE MY MENOPLAN[/mk_fancy_title][vc_single_image image="1775" img_size="full" alignment="center" onclick="custom_link" link="http://mymenoplan.org/create-my-menoplan/"][vc_column_text el_class="assesments-links" css=".vc_custom_1615439481354{margin-top: 10px !important;margin-right: 10px !important;margin-bottom: 10px !important;margin-left: 10px !important;border-top-width: 25px !important;border-right-width: 25px !important;border-bottom-width: 25px !important;border-left-width: 25px !important;padding-top: 10px !important;padding-right: 10px !important;padding-bottom: 10px !important;padding-left: 10px !important;border-left-color: rgba(90,181,158,0.1) !important;border-left-style: solid !important;border-right-color: rgba(90,181,158,0.1) !important;border-right-style: solid !important;border-top-color: rgba(90,181,158,0.1) !important;border-top-style: solid !important;border-bottom-color: rgba(90,181,158,0.1) !important;border-bottom-style: solid !important;}"]

TRACK MY HOT FLASHES

Use this Hot Flash Diary to see how many you have and how much they bother you.

[/vc_column_text][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][vc_column_text el_class="assesments-links" css=".vc_custom_1636414379736{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]

[vc_row fullwidth="true"][vc_column][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_color_style="gradient_color" thin_grandient_color_from="#75d8c0" thin_grandient_color_to="#28b590" thin_gradient_color_angle="horizontal" thickness="4" margin_top="0" margin_bottom="0"][/vc_column][vc_column][mk_padding_divider][mk_fancy_title strip_tags="true" style="true" color="#4f4b51" size="25" font_weight="400" letter_spacing="1" margin_bottom="0" font_family="none" align="center"]SLEEP PROBLEMS & INSOMNIA[/mk_fancy_title][vc_row_inner is_fullwidth_content="false"][vc_column_inner width="2/3"][vc_column_text css=".vc_custom_1617475871945{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]

  • These treatments do not help
  • References

[/vc_column_text][/vc_column_inner][vc_column_inner width="1/3"][vc_column_text css=".vc_custom_1625686832207{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]

[/vc_column_text][vc_raw_html][/vc_raw_html][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][/vc_column][/vc_row][mk_page_section vertical_align="top" bg_image="http://mymenoplan.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/int-q-as-scaled.jpg" bg_position="left center" bg_stretch="true" sidebar="sidebar-1"][vc_column][mk_fancy_title color="#ffffff" size="56" font_weight="100" margin_top="100" margin_bottom="100" font_family="none" align="center" el_class="eldwin pagetitle"]Symptoms[/mk_fancy_title][/vc_column][/mk_page_section][vc_row][vc_column width="2/3"][vc_row_inner el_id="what-sleep"][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][vc_column_text css=".vc_custom_1628007705941{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]WHAT IS IT?

Insomnia is difficulty falling asleep, staying asleep, or waking up too early in the morning. Women with insomnia often feel tired, have low energy, have trouble concentrating, their mood may be disturbed, they may have low libido, and not function as well during the day. To be diagnosed with insomnia, your lack of sleep needs to interfere with daily functioning.

If insomnia happens at least 3 times a week for three or more months, it is considered chronic.[/vc_column_text][vc_row_inner el_id="happen-sleep"][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][vc_column_text css=".vc_custom_1628007813190{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]WHAT'S HAPPENING TO MY BODY?

During the perimenopause period estrogen production becomes erratic and then decreases dramatically once a woman stops menstruating. It is thought that these estrogen changes contribute to the increased risk of insomnia during perimenopause. Some women find that they awake when they have night sweats and then have trouble going back to sleep.[/vc_column_text][vc_row_inner el_id="expect-sleep"][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][vc_column_text css=".vc_custom_1628007839589{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]WHAT TO EXPECT

Insomnia is a common complaint of women during the menopause transition. Complaints increase as women get closer to menopause.

Sleep problems also increase as we age. Other risk factors for insomnia include: poor sleep habits, depression, anxiety, lack of exercise, obstructive sleep apnea, and some medications.[/vc_column_text][vc_row_inner el_id="help-sleep"][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][mk_icon_box icon="mk-icon-check" title="RESEARCH SHOWS THESE TREATMENTS HELP" text_size="17" font_weight="bold" icon_size="medium" margin="0"]

  • Cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia (CBTi)
  • Estrogen pills, patches and creams can decrease the number of nighttime awakenings
  • Exercise 
  • Hypnosis
  • Sedatives and hypnotic drugs are often the first treatment suggested for insomnia.
  • SSRI and SNRI Antidepressants
  • Weight Loss
  • Yoga

[/mk_icon_box][vc_row_inner el_id="may-help-sleep"][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][mk_icon_box icon="mk-icon-circle-o" title="THESE TREATMENTS MAY HELP, BUT WE NEED MORE RESEARCH" text_size="17" font_weight="bold" icon_size="medium" icon_color="#e2d17a" margin="0"]

  • Gabapentin 
  • Mindfulness-based stress reduction
  • Quit smoking
  • If you are awakened with hot flashes you might try cooling techniques 

[/mk_icon_box][vc_row_inner el_id="not-help-sleep"][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][mk_icon_box icon="mk-icon-ban" title="RESEARCH SHOWS THESE TREATMENTS DO NOT HELP" text_size="17" font_weight="bold" icon_size="medium" icon_color="#dd3333" margin="0"]

  • Omega-3 supplements
  • Tai Chi and Qigong  

[/mk_icon_box][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][vc_column_text css=".vc_custom_1617474598732{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"][icon name="asterisk" class="" unprefixed_class=""]  Treatments that are inappropriate or have not been studied for this symptom are not listed.[/vc_column_text][vc_row_inner el_id="references-sleep"][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][mk_toggle title="REFERENCES"]Baglioni C, Bostanova Z, Bacaro V, Benz F, Hertenstein E, Spiegelhalder K, Rücker G, Frase L, Riemann D, Feige B. A Systematic Review and Network Meta-Analysis of Randomized Controlled Trials Evaluating the Evidence Base of Melatonin, Light Exposure, Exercise, and Complementary and Alternative Medicine for Patients with Insomnia Disorder. item.title: Mood, Depression, Anxiety
item.dc:creator: sblair
item.content:encoded:
[vc_row fullwidth="true"][vc_column][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_color_style="gradient_color" thin_grandient_color_from="#75d8c0" thin_grandient_color_to="#28b590" thin_gradient_color_angle="diagonal_left_bottom" thickness="4" margin_top="0" margin_bottom="0"][/vc_column][/vc_row][vc_row][vc_column][mk_padding_divider][mk_fancy_title strip_tags="true" style="true" color="#4f4b51" size="25" font_weight="400" letter_spacing="1" margin_bottom="0" font_family="none" align="center"]MOOD, ANXIETY, & DEPRESSION[/mk_fancy_title][mk_padding_divider size="20"][vc_row_inner][vc_column_inner width="2/3"][vc_column_text css=".vc_custom_1621446188442{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]

  • What is it
  • Should I talk with my health care provider about anxiety? A personalized tool
  • Should I talk with my health care provider about depression? A personalized tool
  • What's happening to my body
  • What to expect
  • Treatments that help
  • Treatments that may help
  • References

[/vc_column_text][/vc_column_inner][vc_column_inner width="1/3"][vc_single_image image="794" img_size="180 x 180" alignment="center"][vc_raw_html][/vc_raw_html][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][/vc_column][vc_column][/vc_column][/vc_row][mk_page_section vertical_align="top" bg_image="http://mymenoplan.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/int-q-as-scaled.jpg" bg_position="left center" bg_stretch="true" sidebar="sidebar-1"][vc_column][mk_fancy_title color="#ffffff" size="56" font_weight="100" margin_top="100" margin_bottom="100" font_family="none" align="center" el_class="eldwin pagetitle"]Symptoms[/mk_fancy_title][/vc_column][/mk_page_section][vc_row][vc_column width="2/3"][vc_row_inner el_id="what-mood"][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="10"][vc_column_text css=".vc_custom_1628008645021{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]WHAT IS IT?

Women are more likely to have depressed mood, major depression, and/or anxiety during perimenopause. While it is normal to occasionally feel down or anxious, or have a moody day, major depression can significantly interfere with your life.

Symptoms of depression can include:

  • loss of interest or pleasure in your activities,
  • weight loss or gain,
  • trouble getting to sleep or feeling sleepy during the day,
  • feeling restless and agitated or else very sluggish and slowed down physically or mentally,
  • being tired and without energy,
  • feeling worthless or guilty,
  • trouble concentrating or making decisions,
  • a sense that something bad is going to happen,
  • a sense of hopelessness,
  • thoughts of suicide, and
  • inability to take care of yourself.

If you have many of these symptoms for two or more weeks, you may have major depression.

Anxiety symptoms include:

  • excessive worrying that interferes with daily functioning,
  • agitation,
  • restlessness,
  • fatigue,
  • difficulty concentrating,
  • irritability,
  • tense muscles,
  • panic attacks, and
  • trouble sleeping.

[/vc_column_text][vc_row_inner el_id="happen-mood"][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][vc_column_text disable_pattern="false" css=".vc_custom_1627882390472{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]WHAT'S HAPPENING TO MY BODY?

We are not completely sure why the risk for depression increases during the menopause transition, but hormone fluctuations likely play a role. Night time hot flashes, or night sweats, and insomnia can contribute to mood changes as well.[/vc_column_text][vc_row_inner el_id="expect-mood"][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][vc_column_text disable_pattern="false" css=".vc_custom_1628008713154{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]WHAT TO EXPECT

Women who are most at risk are those with a history of depression. But even women who have not been depressed before are about 3 times more likely to develop depression during the menopause transition compared to premenopause.  Poor sleep, stress, negative life events, higher body mass index, smoking, younger age at menopause and African American race increase this risk.[/vc_column_text][vc_row_inner el_id="help-mood"][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_top="40" margin_bottom="50"][mk_icon_box icon="mk-icon-check" title="RESEARCH SHOWS THESE TREATMENTS HELP" text_size="17" font_weight="bold" icon_size="medium" margin="0"]

  • Antidepressants (SSRIs, SNRIs)
  • Cognitive behavioral therapy
  • Psychotherapy/talk therapy/counseling: There are many other talk therapies and counseling approaches that are very helpful for treating depression and anxiety and supporting individuals as they experience challenging times in their lives. While most have not been studied specifically in midlife women, there is extensive experience delivering these treatments to women of all ages.
  • Hypnosis

[/mk_icon_box][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][mk_icon_box icon="mk-icon-circle-o" title="THESE TREATMENTS MAY HELP, BUT WE NEED MORE RESEARCH" text_size="17" font_weight="bold" icon_size="medium" icon_color="#e2d17a" margin="0"]

  • Estrogen pill, patches and creams
  • Exercise may help with anxiety and depression
  • Mindfulness-based stress reduction, meditation
  • Paced breathing
  • Quit smoking
  • Yoga
  • Many of the suggestions for how deal with brain fog may help for mood, depression, and anxiety, too.
  • Stay hydrated. Research with adults in general - not necessarily women in the menopause transition - finds that dehydration can affect your mood. The lack of fluids can cause anger, confusion, sadness, tension, and tiredness.

[/mk_icon_box][vc_row_inner el_id="not-help-mood"][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][vc_column_text css=".vc_custom_1617474714025{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"][icon name="asterisk" class="" unprefixed_class=""]  Treatments that are inappropriate or have not been studied for this symptom are not listed.[/vc_column_text][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][vc_row_inner el_id="references-mood"][vc_column_inner][mk_toggle title="REFERENCES"]Amin Z, Canli T, Epperson CN. Effect of estrogen-serotonin interactions on mood and cognition. Behav Cogn Neurosci Rev. 2005; 4:43–58. doi:10.1177/1534582305277152. PMID: 15886402.
