item.title: SOY FOODS AND SUPPLEMENTS
item.dc:creator: katherine
item.content:encoded:
[mk_page_section vertical_align="top" bg_image="http://mymenoplan.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/int-q-as-scaled.jpg" bg_position="left center" bg_stretch="true" sidebar="sidebar-1"][vc_column][mk_fancy_title color="#ffffff" size="56" font_weight="100" margin_top="100" margin_bottom="100" font_family="none" align="center" el_class="eldwin pagetitle"]Treatments[/mk_fancy_title][/vc_column][/mk_page_section][vc_row fullwidth="true"][vc_column][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_color_style="gradient_color" thin_grandient_color_from="#75d8c0" thin_grandient_color_to="#28b590" thin_gradient_color_angle="horizontal" thickness="4" margin_top="0" margin_bottom="0"][/vc_column][/vc_row][vc_row][vc_column][mk_padding_divider][mk_fancy_title strip_tags="true" style="true" color="#4f4b51" size="25" font_weight="400" txt_transform="uppercase" letter_spacing="1" margin_bottom="0" font_family="none" align="center"]SOY FOODS AND SUPPLEMENTS[/mk_fancy_title][mk_padding_divider size="20"][vc_row_inner el_id="what-is-it"][vc_column_inner width="2/3"][vc_column_text disable_pattern="false" css=".vc_custom_1620326744760{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]

  • What is it?
  • Our bottom line: Does it help?
  • May help for these symptoms
  • Risks, side effects, & quality of life concerns
  • If I want to try this, what are my next steps
  • More of the science
  • References

[/vc_column_text][/vc_column_inner][vc_column_inner width="1/3"][vc_single_image image="2116" img_size="full" alignment="center"][vc_column_text el_class="assesments-links" css=".vc_custom_1613676199147{margin: px !important;border-width: px !important;padding: px !important;}"]

[icon name="print" class="" unprefixed_class=""] PRINT PAGE

[/vc_column_text][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][/vc_column][/vc_row][vc_row][vc_column width="2/3"][vc_row_inner el_id="what-Soy"][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][vc_column_text disable_pattern="false" el_class="#what-is-it" css=".vc_custom_1617509342707{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]WHAT IS IT?

Many menopausal age women try soy foods, supplements, and soy powders, to treat their hot flashes. Soybeans, which grow on a bush, are grown around the world. Soy-based foods include soy sauce, tofu, soy milk, soy yogurt, edamame (whole soybeans), miso, and tempeh.  Soy lattes are found in coffee shops. Soy foods are an excellent source of protein.

There has been an interest in soy foods and supplements for menopause because soy contains three phytoestrogens. Phytoestrogen means plant-based estrogen. The phytoestrogens in soy are called “isoflavones” – they have a chemical structure similar to estrogen. The soy isoflavones of greatest interest are genistein and daidzein. Because of their chemical structure, it has been thought that soy foods or supplements with phytoestrogens might relieve hot flashes.

In the gut, bacteria can change daidzein is into a chemical called equol. Equol seems to act like a weak estrogen – but only about 20% of U.S. women can make equol. Soy equol is taken as a supplement.

[/vc_column_text][vc_row_inner el_id="bottom-Soy"][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][vc_column_text css=".vc_custom_1619193169179{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]OUR BOTTOM LINE:  DOES IT HELP?

MAYBE. The evidence for soy isoflavones is weak, but they are not harmful. If soy interests you, it is safe to try it and see if your hot flashes improve. Equol supplements may also help relieve daytime hot flashes. Soy may help with memory issues, as well.[/vc_column_text][vc_row_inner el_id="may-help-soy"][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][mk_icon_box icon="mk-icon-circle-o" title="MAY HELP FOR THESE SYMPTOMS" text_size="17" font_weight="bold" icon_size="medium" icon_color="#e2d17a" margin="0"][/mk_icon_box][vc_row_inner attached="true" el_class="treatment-toggle-fix"][vc_column_inner width="1/6" offset="vc_hidden-sm vc_hidden-xs"][vc_single_image image="792" img_size="40x40" alignment="center"][/vc_column_inner][vc_column_inner el_class="treatment-row-fix" width="5/6"][vc_column_text css=".vc_custom_1619193253818{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]HOT FLASHES

Dozens of studies have looked at the effects of soy foods, supplements, and powders on menopause symptoms. The daily “dose” of isoflavones used in these studies has ranged from 30-200 mg/day, with most using 50-60 mg/day. The study results are very mixed. Overall, they suggest that soy may slightly relieve hot flashes. Soy isoflavones may reduce hot flashes by about 1.3 hot flashes a day. Soy isoflavones do not seem to relieve night sweats and are not recommended for this symptom. The few studies of equol suggest that when taken twice a day and at high enough doses it helps decrease the number and severity of daytime hot flashes. Equol supplements may help with night sweats.[/vc_column_text][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][vc_row_inner attached="true" el_class="treatment-toggle-fix"][vc_column_inner width="1/6" offset="vc_hidden-sm vc_hidden-xs"][vc_single_image image="1218" img_size="40x40" alignment="center"][/vc_column_inner][vc_column_inner el_class="treatment-row-fix" width="5/6"][vc_column_text css=".vc_custom_1619198850149{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]COGNITIVE ISSUES: MEMORY

Soy isoflavines have been found to slightly improve memory in postmenopausal women. More studies are needed in women in perimenopause. Soy was not helpful for other aspects of cognition, such as attention and executive function.[/vc_column_text][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][vc_row_inner el_id="risks-Soy"][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][vc_column_text css=".vc_custom_1617509589848{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]POTENTIAL RISKS & SIDE EFFECTS

Some women report side effects such as upset stomach, bloating, constipation, or nausea.

Soy isoflavones do not harm the uterus, vagina, or breasts, even when taken for up to two years. Excellent studies have found that soy isoflavones are safe for women with breast cancer.

[/vc_column_text][vc_row_inner][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][vc_column_text css=".vc_custom_1617509664076{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]QUALITY OF LIFE EXPECTATIONS

None[/vc_column_text][vc_row_inner el_id="steps-Soy"][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][vc_column_text css=".vc_custom_1617509684738{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]IF I WANT TO TRY THIS TREATMENT WHAT ARE MY NEXT STEPS?

SOY
Start with 50-75 mg/day isoflavones (usually 2 serving of soyfoods or 2 pills a day).

If you think you are being helped, continue, with monitoring for side effects. Use soy isoflavones for 12 weeks to see if your hot flashes improve. Stop if you have bothersome side effects. If soy hasn’t helped you in 12 weeks, try something else.

One serving of a traditional soy food, such as 3-4 oz of tofu or 8 oz of soymilk provides about 25 mg of isoflavones. Soy isoflavone supplements are available and most contain about 25 mg. of isoflavones per pill (about the same as one serving of soy food). There are also soy powders that can be mixed with milk or other liquids (think smoothies).

It is always best to get nutrients from real food. But for those used to a western diet, it is hard to get enough isoflavones from food. Try a serving a day of soymilk or tofu to start. Figure out the mix of food and supplements that works for you. Read labels and take enough pills, powers, and soy foods to reach your 50-75 mg per day goal.

EQUOL
If you want to try equol supplements the best results have been found at daily doses of 100-200mg per day, split into two doses.[/vc_column_text][vc_row_inner el_id="not-used-Soy"][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][mk_icon_box icon="mk-icon-close" title="NOT USED FOR THESE SYMPTOMS" text_size="17" font_weight="bold" icon_color="#a8a8a8" margin="0"]

  • Sleep problems / insomnia
  • Mood, depression, anxiety
  • Heavy irregular periods
  • Low sex drive
  • Pain during sex
  • Vaginal pain, not during sex
  • Bladder control problems
  • Dry eyes
  • Dry hair & skin
  • Physical aches & pains
  • Weight gain

[/mk_icon_box][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][vc_row_inner el_id="science-Soy"][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][mk_toggle title="FOR HEALTH CARE PROVIDERS & THOSE WHO WANT MORE OF THE SCIENCE"]

The evidence on the effects of soy as a treatment for menopause-related hot flashes has been mixed, with modest effects on average. Most studies tested isoflavone pills, but the dosing varied widely, from 30 mg/day up to 200 mg / day. Some studies have examined the impact of dietary soy. Some recent individual studies suggest that perhaps higher doses (100mg/day) of isoflavones are needed to show improvement in hot flashes (J Clin Diagn Res. 2017 ) ,or that treatment longer than 14 weeks are needed to maximize benefits (Br J Clin Pharmacol. 2015).

There have been three major reviews and meta-analyses since 2011 examining soy as a treatment for hot flashes associated with menopause. In 2011, the North American Menopause Association reported that the majority (11 of 14) of the studies in their review show that soy significantly reduced hot flash frequency. The report concluded that a dose a dose of 50 to 60 mg/day over 12 weeks was sufficient to reducing hot flash frequency and severity.

Subsequently, a Cochrane review from 2013 including 43 studies reported there that evidence is conflicting whether use of soy foods or soy supplements reduces the frequency or severity of hot flushes and night sweats. This report acknowledged that many of the trials included in the review were of poor quality. A review and meta-analysis of 21 randomized controlled trials published in 2016 in the Journal of the American Medical Association including concluded that the use of dietary and soy supplements caused a modest reduction in daily hot flashes, but not night sweats. Many of the studies included in this review were considered of poor quality, and symptom alleviation was stronger for studies that were classified with high risk of bias (JAMA 2016).

Soy was once thought to be contraindicated for women with breast cancer. Because it has weak estrogenic properties, clinicians worried that soy foods might cause estrogen sensitive tumors to grow. However, a landmark study in 2009 published in the Journal of the American Medical Association (Shu, Jama 2009) demonstrated for the first time that soy foods were safe for women with breast cancer. In addition, eating soy decreased risk of death from and recurrence of breast cancer. This was true for women who had either estrogen receptor positive and estrogen receptor negative breast tumors. These same results were later confirmed by several more studies. The 2010 Nutrition, Physical Activity and Cancer Survivorship Advisory Committee issued nutrition and physical activity guidelines for cancer survivors and stated, “For the breast cancer survivor, current evidence suggests no adverse effects on recurrence or survival from consuming soy and soy foods, and there is the potential for these foods to exert a positive synergistic effect with tamoxifen”.

The literature on equol (or S-equol) is promising but limited.

[/mk_toggle][vc_row_inner el_id="references-Soy"][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][mk_toggle title="REFERENCES"]

item.title: MEDITATION, MINDFULNESS, MINDFULNESS-BASED STRESS REDUCTION
item.dc:creator: katherine
item.content:encoded:
[mk_page_section vertical_align="top" bg_image="http://mymenoplan.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/int-q-as-scaled.jpg" bg_position="left center" bg_stretch="true" sidebar="sidebar-1"][vc_column][mk_fancy_title color="#ffffff" size="56" font_weight="100" margin_top="100" margin_bottom="100" font_family="none" align="center" el_class="eldwin pagetitle"]Treatments[/mk_fancy_title][/vc_column][/mk_page_section][vc_row fullwidth="true"][vc_column][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_color_style="gradient_color" thin_grandient_color_from="#75d8c0" thin_grandient_color_to="#28b590" thin_gradient_color_angle="horizontal" thickness="4" margin_top="0" margin_bottom="0"][/vc_column][/vc_row][vc_row][vc_column][mk_padding_divider][mk_fancy_title strip_tags="true" style="true" color="#4f4b51" size="25" font_weight="400" txt_transform="uppercase" letter_spacing="1" margin_bottom="0" font_family="none" align="center"]

MEDITATION, MINDFULNESS, MINDFULNESS-BASED STRESS REDUCTION

[/mk_fancy_title][mk_padding_divider size="20"][vc_row_inner el_id="what-is-it"][vc_column_inner width="2/3"][vc_column_text disable_pattern="false" css=".vc_custom_1617515006811{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]

  • What is it?
  • Our bottom line: Does it help?
  • May help for these symptoms
  • Doesn't help for these symptoms
  • Risks, side effects, & quality of life concerns
  • If I want to try this, what are my next steps
  • References

[/vc_column_text][/vc_column_inner][vc_column_inner width="1/3"][vc_single_image image="2123" img_size="full" alignment="center"][vc_column_text el_class="assesments-links" css=".vc_custom_1613676199147{margin: px !important;border-width: px !important;padding: px !important;}"]

[icon name="print" class="" unprefixed_class=""] PRINT PAGE

[/vc_column_text][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][/vc_column][/vc_row][vc_row][vc_column width="2/3"][vc_row_inner el_id="what-meditation"][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][vc_column_text disable_pattern="false" el_class="#what-is-it" css=".vc_custom_1620325298329{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]WHAT IS IT?

Mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR) teaches you to be aware of your thoughts, feelings, and sensations.  You set aside being reactive or judgmental. It can help you have more choice and take wise action in your life. You can develop a non-judgmental acceptance and “open-hearted” experience. The goals are to increase well-being and reduce suffering and distress. It is known for helping people with stress, anxiety, depression, and pain.

MBSR is most often taught in a 6 to 8-week course. It combines mindfulness meditation, body awareness, yoga and exploration of patterns of behavior, thinking, feeling and action.

Meditation and mindfulness are used to reduce stress. They include focused breathing or belly breathing, body scanning, guided imagery, prayer, and other techniques.

[/vc_column_text][vc_row_inner el_id="bottom-meditation"][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][vc_column_text css=".vc_custom_1619724349585{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]OUR BOTTOM LINE:  DOES IT HELP?

MAYBE. Mindfulness-based stress reduction may improve overall quality of life for women with menopause symptoms. It may help you sleep better and put you in a better mood.

NO. MSBR will likely not decrease the number or severity of hot flashes and night sweats.[/vc_column_text][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][vc_row_inner el_id="may-help-meditation"][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][mk_icon_box icon="mk-icon-circle-o" title="MAY HELP FOR THESE SYMPTOMS" text_size="17" font_weight="bold" icon_size="medium" icon_color="#e2d17a" margin="20"][/mk_icon_box][vc_row_inner attached="true" el_class="treatment-toggle-fix"][vc_column_inner width="1/6" offset="vc_hidden-sm vc_hidden-xs"][vc_single_image image="793" img_size="40x40" alignment="center"][/vc_column_inner][vc_column_inner el_class="treatment-row-fix" width="5/6"][vc_column_text disable_pattern="false" css=".vc_custom_1619726891021{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]SLEEP PROBLEMS & INSOMNIA

Mindfulness training has been shown to improve sleep for adults. However, research is needed on women in menopause.[/vc_column_text][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][vc_row_inner attached="true" el_class="treatment-toggle-fix"][vc_column_inner width="1/6" offset="vc_hidden-sm vc_hidden-xs"][vc_single_image image="794" img_size="40x40" alignment="center"][/vc_column_inner][vc_column_inner el_class="treatment-row-fix" width="5/6"][vc_column_text disable_pattern="false" css=".vc_custom_1619724290690{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]MOOD, ANXIETY & DEPRESSION

While not studied specifically in menopausal women, there is some evidence that mindfulness-based stress reduction can help decrease depression and anxiety.[/vc_column_text][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][vc_row_inner attached="true" el_class="treatment-toggle-fix"][vc_column_inner width="1/6" offset="vc_hidden-sm vc_hidden-xs"][vc_single_image image="1220" img_size="40x40" alignment="center"][/vc_column_inner][vc_column_inner el_class="treatment-row-fix" width="5/6"][vc_column_text disable_pattern="false" css=".vc_custom_1619727662446{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]WEIGHT LOSS

Mindfulness-based stress reduction and meditation have helped people lose about 7 pounds in the short-term on average. It is usually combined with another approach, like changes in diet. Indeed, there are programs that combine the two by promoting mindful eating, which can be effective in reducing impulsive eating. Long-term effects of MBSR on weight loss maintenance are not known. The studies were not specifically about menopause-related weight gain.

 [/vc_column_text][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][vc_row_inner el_id="not-help-meditation"][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_icon_box icon="mk-icon-ban" title="DOES NOT HELP THESE SYMPTOMS" text_size="17" font_weight="bold" icon_size="medium" icon_color="#dd5454" margin="0"][/mk_icon_box][vc_row_inner attached="true" el_class="treatment-toggle-fix"][vc_column_inner width="1/6" offset="vc_hidden-sm vc_hidden-xs"][vc_single_image image="792" img_size="40x40" alignment="center"][/vc_column_inner][vc_column_inner el_class="treatment-row-fix" width="5/6"][vc_column_text css=".vc_custom_1617514478758{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]HOT FLASHES AND NIGHT SWEATS

MBSR does not seem to decrease hot flashes, night sweats, or the severity of these symptoms.[/vc_column_text][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][vc_row_inner attached="true" el_class="treatment-toggle-fix"][vc_column_inner width="1/6" offset="vc_hidden-sm vc_hidden-xs"][vc_single_image image="802" img_size="40x40" alignment="center"][/vc_column_inner][vc_column_inner el_class="treatment-row-fix" width="5/6"][vc_column_text disable_pattern="false" css=".vc_custom_1617514498317{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]ACHES AND PAINS

Evidence thus far indicates that MBSR does not decrease pain.[/vc_column_text][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][vc_row_inner el_id="risks-meditation"][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][vc_column_text css=".vc_custom_1617514620136{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]POTENTIAL RISKS & SIDE EFFECTS

There are no know risks of MBSR.[/vc_column_text][vc_row_inner el_id="quality-meditation"][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][vc_column_text css=".vc_custom_1617514446621{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]QUALITY OF LIFE EXPECTATIONS

There is some evidence that MBSR may help with overall menopause related quality of life.[/vc_column_text][vc_row_inner el_id="steps-meditation"][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][vc_column_text css=".vc_custom_1617514652224{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]IF I WANT TO TRY THIS TREATMENT WHAT ARE MY NEXT STEPS?

Classes and programs in MBSR are widely offered. Look for them at hospitals, retreat centers, yoga facilities and meditation centers. Books and on-line programs can also suggest how to use mindfulness.[/vc_column_text][vc_row_inner el_id="not-used-trt"][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][mk_icon_box icon="mk-icon-close" title="NOT USED FOR THESE SYMPTOMS" text_size="17" font_weight="bold" icon_color="#a8a8a8" margin="0"]

  • Bladder control problems
  • Heavy, irregular periods
  • Dry eyes
  • Dry hair & skin
  • Pain with sex
  • Vaginal pain or dryness, not during sex

[/mk_icon_box][vc_row_inner el_id="not-studied-trt"][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][mk_icon_box icon="mk-icon-asterisk" title="NOT STUDIED FOR THESE SYMPTOMS" text_size="17" font_weight="600" icon_color="#a8a8a8" margin="20"]

  • Brain fog, cognitive issues
  • Low sex drive

[/mk_icon_box][vc_row_inner el_id="references-meditation"][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][mk_toggle title="REFERENCES"]

Carrière, K., Khoury, B., Günak, M. M., and Knäuper, B. (2018) Mindfulness‐based interventions for weight loss: a systematic review and meta‐analysis. Obesity Reviews, 19: 164– 177. doi: 10.1111/obr.12623.

Goldberg SB, Tucker RP, Greene PA, Davidson RJ, Wampold BE, Kearny DJ, Simpson TL. Mindfulness-based interventions for psychiatric disorders: A systematic review and meta-analysis. Clin Psychol Rev. 2018;59:52–60. doi:10.1016/j.cpr.2017.10.011. PMID: 29126747

Strauss C, Cavanagh K, Oliver A, Pettman D. Mindfulness-based interventions for people diagnosed with a current episode of an anxiety or depressive disorder: a meta-analysis of randomised controlled trials. PLoS One. 2014;9(4):e96110. Published 2014 Apr 24. doi:10.1371/journal.pone.0096110

Bawa FL, Mercer SW, Atherton RJ, et al. Does mindfulness improve outcomes in patients with chronic pain? Systematic review and meta-analysis. Br J Gen Pract. 2015;65(635):e387–e400. doi:10.3399/bjgp15X685297

Wong C, Yip BH, Gao T, et al. Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR) or Psychoeducation for the Reduction of Menopausal Symptoms: A Randomized, Controlled Clinical Trial. Sci Rep. 2018;8(1):6609. Published 2018 Apr 26. doi:10.1038/s41598-018-24945-4

Chen KW, Berger CC, Manheimer E, et al. Meditative therapies for reducing anxiety: a systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials. Depress Anxiety. 2012;29(7):545–562. doi:10.1002/da.21964

Goyal M, Singh S, Sibinga EM, et al. Meditation programs for psychological stress and well-being: a systematic review and meta-analysis. JAMA Intern Med. 2014;174(3):357–368. doi:10.1001/jamainternmed.2013.13018

van Driel C, de Bock GH, Schroevers MJ, Mourits MJ. Mindfulness-based stress reduction for menopausal symptoms after risk-reducing salpingo-oophorectomy (PURSUE study): a randomised controlled trial. BJOG. 2019;126(3):402‐411. doi:10.1111/1471-0528.15471

Ruffault A, Czernichow S, Hagger MS, Ferrand M, Erichot N, Carette C, Boujut E, Flahault C.  The effects of mindfulness training on weight-loss and health-related behaviours in adults with overweight and obesity: A systematic review and meta-analysis, Obesity Research & Clinical Practice, 11, 5, Supplement 1, 2017, p. 90-111, ISSN 1871-403X, https://doi.org/10.1016/j.orcp.2016.09.002.

Schell LK, Monsef I, Wöckel A, Skoetz N. Mindfulness-based stress reduction for women diagnosed with breast cancer. Cochrane Database Syst Rev. 2019;3(3):CD011518. Published 2019 Mar 27. doi:10.1002/14651858.CD011518.pub2

[/mk_toggle][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="40"][vc_column_text css=".vc_custom_1617119704921{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]Authors: Dr. Katherine Newton, & Dr. Leslie Snyder.  Last reviewed February 15, 2021[/vc_column_text][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_top="40" margin_bottom="50"][/vc_column][vc_column width="1/3" css=".vc_custom_1594159466278{background-position: center !important;background-repeat: no-repeat !important;background-size: cover !important;}"][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][vc_row_inner][vc_column_inner][mk_fancy_title strip_tags="true" color="#404040" size="20" font_weight="400" margin_bottom="0" font_family="none" align="center"]CREATE MY MENOPLAN[/mk_fancy_title][vc_single_image image="1775" img_size="full" alignment="center" onclick="custom_link" link="http://mymenoplan.org/create-my-menoplan/"][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][/vc_column][/vc_row][vc_row][vc_column][/vc_column][/vc_row]

item.title: Tai Chi and Qigong
item.dc:creator: katherine
item.content:encoded:
[mk_page_section vertical_align="top" bg_image="http://mymenoplan.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/int-q-as-scaled.jpg" bg_position="left center" bg_stretch="true" sidebar="sidebar-1"][vc_column][mk_fancy_title color="#ffffff" size="56" font_weight="100" margin_top="100" margin_bottom="100" font_family="none" align="center" el_class="eldwin pagetitle"]Treatments[/mk_fancy_title][/vc_column][/mk_page_section][vc_row fullwidth="true"][vc_column][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_color_style="gradient_color" thin_grandient_color_from="#75d8c0" thin_grandient_color_to="#28b590" thin_gradient_color_angle="horizontal" thickness="4" margin_top="0" margin_bottom="0"][/vc_column][/vc_row][vc_row][vc_column][mk_padding_divider][mk_fancy_title strip_tags="true" style="true" color="#4f4b51" size="25" font_weight="400" txt_transform="uppercase" letter_spacing="1" margin_bottom="0" font_family="none" align="center"]tai chi and qigong[/mk_fancy_title][mk_padding_divider size="20"][vc_row_inner el_id="what-is-it"][vc_column_inner width="2/3"][vc_column_text disable_pattern="false" css=".vc_custom_1619730560073{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]

  • What is it?
  • Our bottom line: Does it help?
  • Risks
  • References

[/vc_column_text][/vc_column_inner][vc_column_inner width="1/3"][vc_single_image image="2228" img_size="full" alignment="center"][vc_column_text el_class="assesments-links" css=".vc_custom_1613676199147{margin: px !important;border-width: px !important;padding: px !important;}"]

[icon name="print" class="" unprefixed_class=""] PRINT PAGE

[/vc_column_text][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][/vc_column][/vc_row][vc_row][vc_column width="2/3"][vc_row_inner el_id="what-Taichi"][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][vc_column_text disable_pattern="false" el_class="#what-is-it" css=".vc_custom_1619730759730{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]WHAT IS IT?

Tai Chi

Tai chi is an ancient Chinese tradition first developed for self-defense. It is practiced as a graceful form of exercise. It involves focused slow movements with deep breathing. There are many styles and forms of tai chi. The major forms are Chen, Yang, Wu, Wu (different words in Chinese) and Sun. Each style has its own features. All styles share the same basic principles.

The principles of tai chi include mind integrated with the body; control of movements and breathing; bringing internal energy, mindfulness, song (loosening 松) and jing (serenity 静). The purpose of tai chi is to cultivate the qi or life energy within us to flow smoothly and powerfully through the body. Total harmony of the inner and outer self comes from the integration of mind and body, empowered through healthy qi through the practice of tai chi.

Tai chi is used for stress reduction and a variety of other health conditions. Often described as meditation in motion, tai chi promotes serenity through gentle, flowing movements.

Qigong

Although tai chi and qigong come from the same roots, and qigong is not a considered a martial art. The qigong movements are less orchestrated than tai chi, and tend to be simpler. Its origins go back over 4,000 year in Chinese culture and over the years many different forms have developed. It is used in traditional Chinese medicine as a preventive and curative practice. There is also a Daoist meditative practice of qigong. During the 40's and 50's the Chinese government tried to standardized these practices and more recently the government has encourage daily morning practice of qigong.

Qigong may include:

  • Dynamic, choreographed, flowing movements that including breath and awareness
  • Static practices that where postures are held
  • Meditative practices that use rhythmic breathing, visualization, chanting and other focusing techniques
  • Addition of herbs, massage and physical manipulation

 

[/vc_column_text][vc_row_inner el_id="bottom-Taichi"][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][vc_column_text css=".vc_custom_1619730637576{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]OUR BOTTOM LINE:  DOES IT HELP?

DON’T KNOW. At this time there is not enough research to say if tai chi or qigong will help improve any menopause symptoms. According to Chinese tradition, both activities may help stave off aches and pains related to aging, but high quality research is needed. Although some studies suggest that tai chi and qigong can help with depression, the research quality is poor, so we think you are better off with trying other interventions. Studies on tai chi and qigong have not address depression and aches and pains menopause specifically.[/vc_column_text][vc_row_inner el_id="risks-taichi"][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="40"][vc_column_text css=".vc_custom_1619730415525{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]RISKS AND SIDE EFFECTS

Neither activity is considered risky. Both are considered forms of "movement therapy."  Research is examining using them with patients with a wide variety of diseases, including Parkinson's, cancer, and diabetes. Tai chi is used to increase balance and prevent falls in older adults.[/vc_column_text][vc_row_inner el_id="references-taichi"][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="40"][mk_toggle title="REFERENCES"]Huang Z, Feng Y, Li Y, et al. Systematic review and meta-analysis: Tai Chi for preventing falls in older adults. BMJ Open 2017;7:e013661. doi: 10.1136/bmjopen-2016-013661

Liu X, Clark J, Siskind D, Williams GM, Byrne G, Yang JL, Doi SA. A systematic review and meta-analysis of the effects of Qigong and Tai Chi for depressive symptoms. Complement Ther Med. 2015 Aug;23(4):516-34. doi: 10.1016/j.ctim.2015.05.001. Epub 2015 May 27. PMID: 26275645.

Marks R. Qigong and Musculoskeletal Pain. Curr Rheumatol Rep. 2019 Nov 16;21(11):59. doi: 10.1007/s11926-019-0861-6. PMID: 31734867.

So WWY, Cai S, Yau SY, Tsang HWH. The Neurophysiological and Psychological Mechanisms of Qigong as a Treatment for Depression: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis. Front Psychiatry. 2019 Nov 18;10:820. doi: 10.3389/fpsyt.2019.00820. PMID: 31824346; PMCID: PMC6880657.[/mk_toggle][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="40"][vc_column_text css=".vc_custom_1619730458262{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]Authors: Dr. Katherine Newton & Dr. Leslie Snyder.  Last reviewed April 29, 2021.[/vc_column_text][/vc_column][vc_column width="1/3" css=".vc_custom_1594159466278{background-position: center !important;background-repeat: no-repeat !important;background-size: cover !important;}"][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][vc_row_inner][vc_column_inner][mk_fancy_title strip_tags="true" color="#404040" size="20" font_weight="400" margin_bottom="0" font_family="none" align="center"]CREATE MY MENOPLAN[/mk_fancy_title][vc_single_image image="1775" img_size="full" alignment="center" onclick="custom_link" link="http://mymenoplan.org/create-my-menoplan/"][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][/vc_column][/vc_row][vc_row][vc_column][/vc_column][/vc_row]

item.title: YOGA
item.dc:creator: katherine
item.content:encoded:
[mk_page_section vertical_align="top" bg_image="http://mymenoplan.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/int-q-as-scaled.jpg" bg_position="left center" bg_stretch="true" sidebar="sidebar-1"][vc_column][mk_fancy_title color="#ffffff" size="56" font_weight="100" margin_top="100" margin_bottom="100" font_family="none" align="center" el_class="eldwin pagetitle"]Treatments[/mk_fancy_title][/vc_column][/mk_page_section][vc_row fullwidth="true"][vc_column][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_color_style="gradient_color" thin_grandient_color_from="#75d8c0" thin_grandient_color_to="#28b590" thin_gradient_color_angle="horizontal" thickness="4" margin_top="0" margin_bottom="0"][/vc_column][/vc_row][vc_row][vc_column][mk_padding_divider][mk_fancy_title strip_tags="true" style="true" color="#4f4b51" size="25" font_weight="400" txt_transform="uppercase" letter_spacing="1" margin_bottom="0" font_family="none" align="center"]yoga[/mk_fancy_title][mk_padding_divider size="20"][vc_row_inner el_id="what-is-it"][vc_column_inner width="2/3"][vc_column_text disable_pattern="false" css=".vc_custom_1617563737210{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]

  • What is it?
  • Our bottom line: Does it help?
  • Helps for these symptoms
  • May help for these symptoms
  • Risks, side effects, & quality of life concerns
  • If I want to try this, what are my next steps
  • More of the science
  • References

[/vc_column_text][/vc_column_inner][vc_column_inner width="1/3"][vc_single_image image="2125" img_size="full" alignment="center"][vc_column_text el_class="assesments-links" css=".vc_custom_1613676199147{margin: px !important;border-width: px !important;padding: px !important;}"]

[icon name="print" class="" unprefixed_class=""] PRINT PAGE

[/vc_column_text][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][/vc_column][/vc_row][vc_row][vc_column width="2/3"][vc_row_inner el_id="what-yoga"][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][vc_column_text disable_pattern="false" el_class="#what-is-it" css=".vc_custom_1621961904219{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]WHAT IS IT?

Yoga is an ancient approach to health and wellness. It has grown in popularity in the U.S. since the 1970s. It often includes movements and poses, breathing techniques, relaxation techniques, and meditation. The types of yoga studied for menopause include hatha yoga, viniyoga, integral yoga, integrative yoga and restorative yoga.  These are gentle yoga forms that are right for midlife and older women who may not have done yoga before.  The more vigorous types of yoga such as yoga flow and hot yoga have not been studied.[/vc_column_text][vc_row_inner el_id="bottom-yoga"][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][vc_column_text css=".vc_custom_1617562436155{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]OUR BOTTOM LINE:  DOES IT HELP?

MAYBE. While yoga won’t decrease the number of hot flashes or night sweats you have, you may be less bothered by them. It may also help your mood and help you sleep better.  It is worth a try.[/vc_column_text][vc_row_inner el_id="helps-yoga"][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][mk_icon_box icon="mk-icon-check" title="HELPS FOR THESE SYMPTOMS" text_size="17" font_weight="bold" icon_size="medium" margin="0"][/mk_icon_box][vc_row_inner attached="true" el_class="treatment-toggle-fix"][vc_column_inner width="1/6" offset="vc_hidden-sm vc_hidden-xs"][vc_single_image image="792" img_size="40x40" alignment="center"][/vc_column_inner][vc_column_inner el_class="treatment-row-fix" width="5/6"][vc_column_text css=".vc_custom_1617562560790{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]HOT FLASHES AND NIGHT SWEATS

Studies of yoga find no decrease in hot flashes and night sweats frequency, but it does seem to decrease how bothered women are by them. [/vc_column_text][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][vc_row_inner attached="true" el_class="treatment-toggle-fix"][vc_column_inner width="1/6" offset="vc_hidden-sm vc_hidden-xs"][vc_single_image image="793" img_size="40x40" alignment="center"][/vc_column_inner][vc_column_inner el_class="treatment-row-fix" width="5/6"][vc_column_text disable_pattern="false" css=".vc_custom_1617562587111{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]SLEEP PROBLEMS & INSOMNIA

Yoga seems to improve sleep in women whose sleep is disturbed by night sweats.[/vc_column_text][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][vc_row_inner el_id="may-help-yoga"][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][mk_icon_box icon="mk-icon-circle-o" title="MAY HELP FOR THESE SYMPTOMS" text_size="17" font_weight="bold" icon_size="medium" icon_color="#e2d17a" margin="20"][/mk_icon_box][vc_row_inner attached="true" el_class="treatment-toggle-fix"][vc_column_inner width="1/6" offset="vc_hidden-sm vc_hidden-xs"][vc_single_image image="794" img_size="40x40" alignment="center"][/vc_column_inner][vc_column_inner el_class="treatment-row-fix" width="5/6"][vc_column_text disable_pattern="false" css=".vc_custom_1617562611128{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]MOOD, ANXIETY & DEPRESSION

Yoga may help. It may have about the same effect as exercise in improving mood overall. [/vc_column_text][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][vc_row_inner attached="true" el_class="treatment-toggle-fix"][vc_column_inner width="1/6" offset="vc_hidden-sm vc_hidden-xs"][vc_single_image image="795" img_size="40x40" alignment="center"][/vc_column_inner][vc_column_inner el_class="treatment-row-fix" width="5/6"][vc_column_text disable_pattern="false" css=".vc_custom_1619736260058{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]VAGINAL PAIN & DRYNESS, NOT DURING SEX[/vc_column_text][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][vc_row_inner attached="true" el_class="treatment-toggle-fix"][vc_column_inner width="1/6" offset="vc_hidden-sm vc_hidden-xs"][vc_single_image image="1223" img_size="40x40" alignment="center"][/vc_column_inner][vc_column_inner el_class="treatment-row-fix" width="5/6"][vc_column_text disable_pattern="false" css=".vc_custom_1619736128065{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]PAIN DURING SEX[/vc_column_text][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][vc_row_inner attached="true" el_class="treatment-toggle-fix"][vc_column_inner width="1/6" offset="vc_hidden-sm vc_hidden-xs"][vc_single_image image="1217" img_size="40x40" alignment="center"][/vc_column_inner][vc_column_inner el_class="treatment-row-fix" width="5/6"][vc_column_text disable_pattern="false" css=".vc_custom_1619736228667{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]BLADDER CONTROL & INCONTINENCE

When vaginal dryness, difficulty with sexual intercourse, and bladder control problems have been studied together it looks like yoga may help a little. But we cannot tell if yoga specifically helps any one of these symptoms on its own. [/vc_column_text][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][vc_row_inner el_id="risks-yoga"][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][vc_column_text css=".vc_custom_1617563222468{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]POTENTIAL RISKS & SIDE EFFECTS

No serious side effects or risks have been reported in the studies of yoga as a treatment for menopause symptoms[/vc_column_text][vc_row_inner][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][vc_column_text css=".vc_custom_1619719447437{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]QUALITY OF LIFE EXPECTATIONS

To the degree that yoga may improve some symptoms it may improve your quality of life.[/vc_column_text][vc_row_inner el_id="steps-yoga"][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][vc_column_text css=".vc_custom_1621961996822{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]IF I WANT TO TRY THIS TREATMENT WHAT ARE MY NEXT STEPS?

  • Yoga classes are offered at community centers, senior centers, and private studios. There are also DVDs available for sale or at public libraries. 
  • There are different types of yoga, and the ones that have been studied for menopause include gentle yoga, viniyoga, restorative yoga, integral yoga and integrative yoga. More vigorous forms of yoga such as hot yoga and yoga flow have not been studied for menopause symptoms, so it is not known how well they work.
  • Many yoga classes are also offered on line.
  • There is no standardized or certified yoga specifically for treating menopause symptoms

[/vc_column_text][vc_row_inner el_id="not-used-yoga"][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][mk_icon_box icon="mk-icon-close" title="NOT USED FOR THESE SYMPTOMS" text_size="17" font_weight="bold" icon_color="#a8a8a8" margin="0"]

  • Heavy, irregular periods
  • Low sex drive
  • Vaginal pain during sex
  • Dry eyes
  • Dry hair & skin
  • Brain fog, cognitive issues
  • Physical aches & pains
  • Weight gain

[/mk_icon_box][vc_row_inner el_id="not-studied-yoga"][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][mk_icon_box icon="mk-icon-asterisk" title="NOT STUDIED FOR THESE SYMPTOMS" text_size="17" font_weight="600" icon_color="#a8a8a8" margin="20"]

  • Low sex drive
  • Physical symptoms/aches & pains (other than low back pain and fibromyalgia)

[/mk_icon_box][vc_row_inner el_id="science-yoga"][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][mk_toggle title="FOR HEALTH CARE PROVIDERS & THOSE WHO WANT MORE OF THE SCIENCE"]

In 2018, the most recent review of yoga for menopause symptoms found 13 studies with 1,306 participants in total (Cramer 2018 Maturitas):   All studies included postures, 11 included breathing techniques, and 8 included meditation. In these studies, Yoga classes were held 1-3 times/week, over 4-16 weeks, with or without meditation, breathing or relaxation components. Duration varied from 20 minutes to 2 hours per session. Some studies included home practice. To our knowledge hot yoga and yoga flow type classes have not been studied for menopause. 

A variety of symptoms could potentially be addressed with yoga:

  • Total menopause symptoms
  • Hot Flash frequency
  • Hot Flash severity
  • Psychological symptoms such as mood, anxiety and depression
  • Sleep/insomnia
  • Quality of life
  • Sexual quality of life

[/mk_toggle][vc_row_inner el_id="references-yoga"][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][mk_toggle title="REFERENCES"]

Buchanan DT, Landis CA, Hohensee C, Guthrie KA, Otte JL, Paudel M, Anderson GL, Caan B, Freeman EW, Joffe H, LaCroix AZ, Newton KM, Reed SD, Ensrud KE. Effects of Yoga and Aerobic Exercise on Actigraphic Sleep Parameters in Menopausal Women with Hot Flashes.

Cramer H1, Lauche R, Langhorst J, Dobos G. Effectiveness of yoga for menopausal symptoms: a systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials. Evid Based Complement Alternat Med. 2012;2012:863905. doi: 10.1155/2012/863905. PMID: 23304220

Drewe J, Bucher KA, Zahner C. A systematic review of non-hormonal treatments of vasomotor symptoms in climacteric and cancer patients. SpringerPlus. 2015;4:65. Published 2015 Feb 10. doi:10.1186/s40064-015-0808-y. PMID: 25713759

PMID: 26241433

PMID: 27261984 Free PMC Article

NAMS. Nonhormonal management of menopause-associated vasomotor symptoms: 2015 position statement of The North American Menopause Society. Menopause. 2015;22(11):1155-1174. doi:10.1097/GME.0000000000000546. PMID: 26382310

[/mk_toggle][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="40"][vc_column_text css=".vc_custom_1617119704921{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]Authors: Dr. Katherine Newton, & Dr. Leslie Snyder.  Last reviewed February 15, 2021[/vc_column_text][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_top="40" margin_bottom="50"][/vc_column][vc_column width="1/3" css=".vc_custom_1594159466278{background-position: center !important;background-repeat: no-repeat !important;background-size: cover !important;}"][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][vc_row_inner][vc_column_inner][mk_fancy_title strip_tags="true" color="#404040" size="20" font_weight="400" margin_bottom="0" font_family="none" align="center"]CREATE MY MENOPLAN[/mk_fancy_title][vc_single_image image="1775" img_size="full" alignment="center" onclick="custom_link" link="http://mymenoplan.org/create-my-menoplan/"][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][/vc_column][/vc_row][vc_row][vc_column][/vc_column][/vc_row]

item.title: PACED BREATHING
item.dc:creator: katherine
item.content:encoded:
[mk_page_section vertical_align="top" bg_image="http://mymenoplan.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/int-q-as-scaled.jpg" bg_position="left center" bg_stretch="true" sidebar="sidebar-1"][vc_column][mk_fancy_title color="#ffffff" size="56" font_weight="100" margin_top="100" margin_bottom="100" font_family="none" align="center" el_class="eldwin pagetitle"]Treatments[/mk_fancy_title][/vc_column][/mk_page_section][vc_row fullwidth="true"][vc_column][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_color_style="gradient_color" thin_grandient_color_from="#75d8c0" thin_grandient_color_to="#28b590" thin_gradient_color_angle="horizontal" thickness="4" margin_top="0" margin_bottom="0"][/vc_column][/vc_row][vc_row][vc_column][mk_padding_divider][mk_fancy_title strip_tags="true" style="true" color="#4f4b51" size="25" font_weight="400" txt_transform="uppercase" letter_spacing="1" margin_bottom="0" font_family="none" align="center"]paced breathing[/mk_fancy_title][mk_padding_divider size="20"][vc_row_inner el_id="what-is-it"][vc_column_inner width="2/3"][vc_column_text disable_pattern="false" css=".vc_custom_1620324951744{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]

  • What is it?
  • Our bottom line: Does it help?
  • May help for these symptoms
  • Doesn't help for these symptoms
  • Risks, side effects, & quality of life concerns
  • If I want to try this, what are my next steps
  • References

[/vc_column_text][/vc_column_inner][vc_column_inner width="1/3"][vc_single_image image="2227" img_size="full" alignment="center"][vc_column_text el_class="assesments-links" css=".vc_custom_1613676199147{margin: px !important;border-width: px !important;padding: px !important;}"]

[icon name="print" class="" unprefixed_class=""] PRINT PAGE

[/vc_column_text][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][/vc_column][/vc_row][vc_row][vc_column width="2/3"][vc_row_inner el_id="what-paced"][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][vc_column_text disable_pattern="false" el_class="#what-is-it" css=".vc_custom_1619757774128{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]WHAT IS IT?

Paced breathing is a relaxation technique used to slow breathing. It prolongs the time spent breathing in (for example, to the count of 4) and breathing out (for example to the count of 6). It can be done once or twice a day to help you relax, or when you have symptoms.

There are apps that can help with paced breathing. There are also books, CDs, and YouTube videos to help people learn you control your breathing rate. Some clinicians may offer biofeedback training to help you learn to control your breath. You may see new devices on the market, too.

Paced breathing can also be done as part of mediation, mindfulness, yoga, tai chi, or Qigong practice.

Paced breathing has been shown to have positive effects on heart rate variability (HRV). HRV, in turn, is related to overall mortality and heart health. This is an active area of research, so we should learn more in the coming years.

[/vc_column_text][vc_row_inner el_id="bottom-paced"][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][vc_column_text css=".vc_custom_1619731047832{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]OUR BOTTOM LINE:  DOES IT HELP?

MAYBE. It may help with anxiety and it's easy to try. It won't hurt you.

NO. Paced breathing does not help with hot flashes.[/vc_column_text][vc_row_inner el_id="may-help-paced"][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][mk_icon_box icon="mk-icon-circle-o" title="MAY HELP FOR THESE SYMPTOMS" text_size="17" font_weight="bold" icon_size="medium" icon_color="#e2d17a" margin="20"][/mk_icon_box][vc_row_inner attached="true" el_class="treatment-toggle-fix"][vc_column_inner width="1/6" offset="vc_hidden-sm vc_hidden-xs"][vc_single_image image="794" img_size="40x40" alignment="center"][/vc_column_inner][vc_column_inner el_class="treatment-row-fix" width="5/6"][vc_column_text disable_pattern="false" css=".vc_custom_1617564188730{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]MOOD, ANXIETY & DEPRESSION

While not studied specifically in menopausal women, slow paced breathing techniques at approximately 6 breaths per minute help against stress and anxiety.[/vc_column_text][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][vc_row_inner el_id="not-help-paced"][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][mk_icon_box icon="mk-icon-ban" title="DOES NOT HELP THESE SYMPTOMS" text_size="17" font_weight="bold" icon_size="medium" icon_color="#dd5454" margin="0"][/mk_icon_box][vc_row_inner attached="true" el_class="treatment-toggle-fix"][vc_column_inner width="1/6" offset="vc_hidden-sm vc_hidden-xs"][vc_single_image image="792" img_size="40x40" alignment="center"][/vc_column_inner][vc_column_inner el_class="treatment-row-fix" width="5/6"][vc_column_text css=".vc_custom_1617564210590{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]HOT FLASHES AND NIGHT SWEATS

Studies of paced breathing find no impact on hot flashes and night sweats frequency, severity or interference.[/vc_column_text][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][vc_row_inner el_id="risks-paced"][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][vc_column_text css=".vc_custom_1619734311702{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]POTENTIAL RISKS & SIDE EFFECTS

Some people may get lightheaded when trying to control their rate of breathing. Its normal to sit down when you practice paced respiration, but lay down if you feel light headed.[/vc_column_text][vc_row_inner el_id="quality-trt"][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][vc_column_text css=".vc_custom_1617564814228{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]QUALITY OF LIFE EXPECTATIONS

NONE[/vc_column_text][vc_row_inner el_id="steps-paced"][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][vc_column_text css=".vc_custom_1619732806279{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]IF I WANT TO TRY THIS TREATMENT WHAT ARE MY NEXT STEPS?

You can try it on your own for a few weeks to see if it makes a difference. We recommend using a diary to track your level of anxiety. Note your anxiety level daily and how many times you practiced paced respiration during the day.  You can use our assessment tool to measure how anxious you were.

There are apps that can help you time your breaths. But you can also count on your own.

Sit comfortably. The goal is 10 breaths a minute. Breath slowly, counting in for 4 and out for 6. To breathe out longer than you breathe in, it can help to exhale through your mouth. Keep this up for 2 minutes at first, but gradually increase to about 10 minutes each time. Do it at least once a day. It's relaxing, so you may want to do it more![/vc_column_text][vc_row_inner el_id="not-used-paced"][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][mk_icon_box icon="mk-icon-close" title="NOT USED FOR THESE SYMPTOMS" text_size="17" font_weight="bold" icon_color="#a8a8a8" margin="0"]

  • Heavy, irregular periods
  • Sleep problems / insomnia
  • Pain with sex
  • Vaginal pain or dryness, not during sex
  • Low sex drive
  • Brain fog, cognitive issues
  • Bladder control problems
  • Physical symptoms/aches & pains
  • Weight gain

[/mk_icon_box][vc_row_inner el_id="references-paced"][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][mk_toggle title="REFERENCES"]

Carpenter JS, Burns DS, Wu J, Otte JL, Schneider B, Ryker K, Tallman E, Yu MJ. Paced respiration for vasomotor and other menopausal symptoms: a randomized, controlled trial. Gen Intern Med. 2013 Feb;28(2):193-200. doi: 10.1007/s11606-012-2202-6. PMID: 22936289 Free PMC Article

item.title: VAGINAL DILATORS
item.dc:creator: katherine
item.content:encoded:
[vc_row][vc_column][vc_column_text]vaginal[/vc_column_text][/vc_column][/vc_row][mk_page_section vertical_align="top" bg_image="http://mymenoplan.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/int-q-as-scaled.jpg" bg_position="left center" bg_stretch="true" sidebar="sidebar-1"][vc_column][mk_fancy_title color="#ffffff" size="56" font_weight="100" margin_top="100" margin_bottom="100" font_family="none" align="center" el_class="eldwin pagetitle"]Treatments[/mk_fancy_title][/vc_column][/mk_page_section][vc_row fullwidth="true"][vc_column][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_color_style="gradient_color" thin_grandient_color_from="#75d8c0" thin_grandient_color_to="#28b590" thin_gradient_color_angle="horizontal" thickness="4" margin_top="0" margin_bottom="0"][/vc_column][/vc_row][vc_row][vc_column][mk_padding_divider][mk_fancy_title strip_tags="true" style="true" color="#4f4b51" size="25" font_weight="400" txt_transform="uppercase" letter_spacing="1" margin_bottom="0" font_family="none" align="center"]vaginal dilators[/mk_fancy_title][mk_padding_divider size="20"][vc_row_inner el_id="what-is-it"][vc_column_inner width="2/3"][vc_column_text disable_pattern="false" css=".vc_custom_1619715377578{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]

  • What is it?
  • Our bottom line: Does it help?
  • May help for these symptoms
  • Risks, side effects, & quality of life concerns
  • If I want to try this, what are my next steps
  • References

[/vc_column_text][/vc_column_inner][vc_column_inner width="1/3"][vc_single_image image="2879" img_size="full" alignment="center"][vc_column_text el_class="assesments-links" css=".vc_custom_1613676199147{margin: px !important;border-width: px !important;padding: px !important;}"]

[icon name="print" class="" unprefixed_class=""] PRINT PAGE

[/vc_column_text][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][/vc_column][/vc_row][vc_row][vc_column width="2/3"][vc_row_inner el_id="what-dilate"][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][vc_column_text disable_pattern="false" el_class="#what-is-it" css=".vc_custom_1621364413967{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]WHAT IS IT?

After menopause the vagina gets drier, less stretchy, narrower, and shorter. These changes can make the vagina feel too tight and make sexual penetration painful. Vaginal dilators are tube-shaped devices, usually made of plastic. They are used to stretch the vagina and make sexual penetration less painful. They usually come in a kit that has dilators of different sizes. The smallest ones are usually about the size of a finger. You start with the smallest one that is tolerable and increase the dilator size over time. Firm plastic dilators are best because they are better at stretching the vagina than soft silicone dilators.[/vc_column_text][vc_row_inner el_id="bottom-dilate"][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][vc_column_text css=".vc_custom_1619645971768{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]OUR BOTTOM LINE:  DOES IT HELP?

YES. If your vagina feels too tight, and using lubricants, moisturizers or vaginal estrogen has not helped, you could try this therapy. Overall, it is a low risk treatment. It can be very helpful for some people.

Vaginal dilators can work, but many women shy away from using them. If the idea of using them makes you uneasy, or shy, consider talking about it with a women’s healthcare specialist. You may also try vaginal physical therapy. Often dilators are used as part of a physical therapy program.

Sometimes women with vaginal problems have difficulty talking with their partner about it. To improve communication with your partner, a counselor can be helpful.

[/vc_column_text][vc_row_inner el_id="may-help-dilate"][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][mk_icon_box icon="mk-icon-circle-o" title="MAY HELP FOR THESE SYMPTOMS" text_size="17" font_weight="bold" icon_size="medium" icon_color="#e2d17a" margin="20"][/mk_icon_box][vc_row_inner attached="true" el_class="treatment-toggle-fix"][vc_column_inner width="1/6" offset="vc_hidden-sm vc_hidden-xs"][vc_single_image image="1223" img_size="40x40" alignment="center"][/vc_column_inner][vc_column_inner el_class="treatment-row-fix" width="5/6"][vc_column_text disable_pattern="false" css=".vc_custom_1617565426073{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]PAIN DURING SEX

There have been very few studies of the use of vaginal dilators in perimenopausal and menopausal women with vaginal tightness and pain during sex. The little data we have indicates that this therapy may be useful.[/vc_column_text][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][vc_row_inner el_id="risks-dilate"][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][vc_column_text css=".vc_custom_1617565460632{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]POTENTIAL RISKS & SIDE EFFECTS

It is normal to have some spotting after using the dilator. Very rarely, a dilator can cause a vaginal tear, especially if excessive force is used.  Be gentle, and if having any difficulty, ask your health care provider or physical therapist for assistance with how to place the dilator.[/vc_column_text][vc_row_inner el_id="quality-trt"][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][vc_column_text css=".vc_custom_1617565521038{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]QUALITY OF LIFE EXPECTATIONS

We don't have any information on whether vaginal dilators help with sexual quality of life.[/vc_column_text][vc_row_inner el_id="steps-dilate"][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][vc_column_text css=".vc_custom_1617565481644{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]IF I WANT TO TRY THIS TREATMENT WHAT ARE MY NEXT STEPS?

Vaginal dilators can be purchased online. If you decide you want to try them you might discuss it with your health care provider first. Some health plans provide guidance for using this therapy and may send you to a physical therapist with training in this therapy.

There are many web sites with instructions about how to use vaginal dilators. The kits also come with instructions. The dilator is inserted with lubrication, and over time the size of dilator is gradually increased.  It should be used 3-4 times a week for 10-15 minutes at a time. Do not use it two days in a row. This gives the vagina time to recover from the stretching.

[/vc_column_text][vc_row_inner el_id="not-used-dilate"][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][mk_icon_box icon="mk-icon-close" title="NOT USED FOR THESE SYMPTOMS" text_size="17" font_weight="bold" icon_color="#a8a8a8" margin="0"]

  • Hot flashes and night sweats
  • Sleep problems / insomnia
  • Mood, anxiety and depression
  • Heavy, irregular periods
  • Dry eyes
  • Dry hair & skin
  • Brain fog, cognitive issues
  • Bladder control problems
  • Physical aches and pains
  • Weight gain

[/mk_icon_box][vc_row_inner el_id="not-studied-dilate"][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][mk_icon_box icon="mk-icon-asterisk" title="NOT STUDIED FOR THESE SYMPTOMS" text_size="17" font_weight="600" icon_color="#a8a8a8" margin="20"]

  • Vaginal pain or dryness, not during sex
  • Low sex drive

[/mk_icon_box][vc_row_inner el_id="references-dilate"][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][mk_toggle title="REFERENCES"]

Kagan R, Kellogg-Spadt S, Parish SJ. Practical Treatment Considerations in the Management of Genitourinary Syndrome of Menopause Drugs Aging. 2019; 36(10): 897–908. Published online 2019 Aug 26. doi: 10.1007/s40266-019-00700-w. PMID: 31452067

Murina F, Bernorio R, Palmiotto R. The use of amielle vaginal trainers as adjuvant in the treatment of vestibulodynia: an observational multicentric study. Medscape J Med. 2008;10(1):23. Published 2008 Jan 30. PMID: 18324333

[/mk_toggle][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="40"][vc_column_text css=".vc_custom_1617119704921{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]Authors: Dr. Katherine Newton, & Dr. Leslie Snyder.  Last reviewed February 15, 2021[/vc_column_text][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_top="40" margin_bottom="50"][/vc_column][vc_column width="1/3" css=".vc_custom_1594159466278{background-position: center !important;background-repeat: no-repeat !important;background-size: cover !important;}"][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][vc_row_inner][vc_column_inner][mk_fancy_title strip_tags="true" color="#404040" size="20" font_weight="400" margin_bottom="0" font_family="none" align="center"]CREATE MY MENOPLAN[/mk_fancy_title][vc_single_image image="1775" img_size="full" alignment="center" onclick="custom_link" link="http://mymenoplan.org/create-my-menoplan/"][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][/vc_column][/vc_row][vc_row][vc_column][/vc_column][/vc_row]

item.title: PELVIC FLOOR PHYSICAL THERAPY
item.dc:creator: katherine
item.content:encoded:
[mk_page_section vertical_align="top" bg_image="http://mymenoplan.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/int-q-as-scaled.jpg" bg_position="left center" bg_stretch="true" sidebar="sidebar-1"][vc_column][mk_fancy_title color="#ffffff" size="56" font_weight="100" margin_top="100" margin_bottom="100" font_family="none" align="center" el_class="eldwin pagetitle"]Treatments[/mk_fancy_title][/vc_column][/mk_page_section][vc_row fullwidth="true"][vc_column][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_color_style="gradient_color" thin_grandient_color_from="#75d8c0" thin_grandient_color_to="#28b590" thin_gradient_color_angle="horizontal" thickness="4" margin_top="0" margin_bottom="0"][/vc_column][/vc_row][vc_row][vc_column][mk_padding_divider][mk_fancy_title strip_tags="true" style="true" color="#4f4b51" size="25" font_weight="400" txt_transform="uppercase" letter_spacing="1" margin_bottom="0" font_family="none" align="center"]PELVIC PHYSICAL THERAPY[/mk_fancy_title][mk_padding_divider size="20"][vc_row_inner el_id="what-is-it"][vc_column_inner width="2/3"][vc_column_text disable_pattern="false" css=".vc_custom_1617570073900{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]

  • What is it?
  • Our bottom line: Does it help?
  • Helps for these symptoms
  • Risks, side effects, & quality of life concerns
  • If I want to try this, what are my next steps
  • More of the science
  • References

[/vc_column_text][/vc_column_inner][vc_column_inner width="1/3"][vc_single_image image="2134" img_size="full" alignment="center"][vc_column_text el_class="assesments-links" css=".vc_custom_1613676199147{margin: px !important;border-width: px !important;padding: px !important;}"]

[icon name="print" class="" unprefixed_class=""] PRINT PAGE

[/vc_column_text][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][/vc_column][/vc_row][vc_row][vc_column width="2/3"][vc_row_inner el_id="what-vagPT"][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][vc_column_text disable_pattern="false" el_class="#what-is-it" css=".vc_custom_1621890644721{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]WHAT IS IT?

Pelvis floor physical therapy (PT) is used for both vaginal pain and for urinary incontinence.

With pelvic floor PT a physical therapist assesses the function and strength of the lower pelvis muscles. The PT uses various techniques to make vaginal penetration easier and ease vaginal pain. Biofeedback sensors may be used in the vagina to measure how much you can contract the vaginal muscles. The therapist may teach you breathing exercises to help relax tense pelvic floor muscles. You may be given pelvic muscle exercises to do such as Kegels (also called pelvic floor muscle training or PFMT) . The therapist may use massage, which may include massage of muscles through the vagina. This massage will stretch and release tissue within the pelvis. The therapist may also show you how to use vaginal dilators. The intent is to improve vaginal or pelvic pain.

PT is also used to help with urinary incontinence. In this case the focus is on strengthening the pelvic floor muscles.

[/vc_column_text][vc_row_inner el_id="bottom-vagPT"][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][vc_column_text css=".vc_custom_1621890661310{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]OUR BOTTOM LINE:  DOES IT HELP?

YES.  Working with a physical therapist trained in pelvic floor PT may help with vaginal pain with sex, and with urinary incontinence.

A common and normal response to pain is to tense up. For many women with vaginal pain or pain with sex, pelvic floor muscle tension becomes a part of the problem – even if it was not the root cause of the problem. Decreasing that pelvic floor tension may be highly effective and is exceptionally low risk.

Pelvic floor muscle training (PFMT), also known as Kegels, helps many women with incontinence. While some women can do these on their own, a trained physical therapist can help ensure you are doing them correctly and measure your progress.

[/vc_column_text][vc_row_inner el_id="helps-vagPT"][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][mk_icon_box icon="mk-icon-check" title="HELPS FOR THESE SYMPTOMS" text_size="17" font_weight="bold" icon_size="medium" margin="0"][/mk_icon_box][vc_row_inner attached="true" el_class="treatment-toggle-fix"][vc_column_inner width="1/6" offset="vc_hidden-sm vc_hidden-xs"][vc_single_image image="1223" img_size="40x40" alignment="center"][/vc_column_inner][vc_column_inner el_class="treatment-row-fix" width="5/6"][vc_column_text disable_pattern="false" css=".vc_custom_1617569451963{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]PAIN DURING SEX

The small number of current studies suggest that physical therapy for pain with sex decreases pain scores. But most of these studies were done in women where pain was not related to menopause.[/vc_column_text][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][vc_row_inner attached="true" el_class="treatment-toggle-fix"][vc_column_inner width="1/6" offset="vc_hidden-sm vc_hidden-xs"][vc_single_image image="1217" img_size="40x40" alignment="center"][/vc_column_inner][vc_column_inner el_class="treatment-row-fix" width="5/6"][vc_column_text disable_pattern="false" css=".vc_custom_1619646368135{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]BLADDER CONTROL PROBLEMS

Pelvic floor muscle training exercises (also known as Kegels) helps decrease the number of incontinent episodes. For some women incontinence goes away completely. But, they must be done correctly in order to work.[/vc_column_text][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][vc_row_inner el_id="risks-vagPT"][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][vc_column_text css=".vc_custom_1617569578872{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]POTENTIAL RISKS & SIDE EFFECTS

The prospect of pelvic floor physical therapy often makes people feel uncomfortable, shy or nervous. Physical therapy can sometimes be uncomfortable, in any area of the body, but a good physical therapist will listen to you and will do their best to put you at ease and avoid causing pain.[/vc_column_text][vc_row_inner el_id="quality-vagPT"][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][vc_column_text css=".vc_custom_1617569593736{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]QUALITY OF LIFE EXPECTATIONS

NONE[/vc_column_text][vc_row_inner el_id="steps-vagPT"][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][vc_column_text css=".vc_custom_1617569641193{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]IF I WANT TO TRY THIS TREATMENT WHAT ARE MY NEXT STEPS?

Find a physical therapist who focuses on pelvic floor physical therapy.

The National Vulvodynia Association website is a good resource to find a therapist with experience treating vaginal pain and pain with sex

For urinary incontinence look for a therapist that specializes in women’s health, pelvic-floor dysfunction, and urinary incontinence. Here’s a tool that can help you find the right type of physical therapist near you, from the American Physical Therapy Association. https://aptaapps.apta.org/APTAPTDirectory/FindAPTDirectory.aspx

[/vc_column_text][vc_row_inner el_id="not-studied-vagPT"][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][mk_icon_box icon="mk-icon-close" title="NOT USED FOR THESE SYMPTOMS" text_size="17" font_weight="600" icon_color="#a8a8a8" margin="20"]

  • Hot flashes and night sweats
  • Sleep problems / insomnia
  • Mood, depression, anxiety
  • Heavy irregular periods
  • Brain fog / cognitive issues
  • Dry eyes
  • Dry hair & skin
  • Physical aches & pains
  • Weight gain

[/mk_icon_box][vc_row_inner][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][mk_icon_box icon="mk-icon-asterisk" title="NOT STUDIED FOR THESE SYMPTOMS" text_size="17" font_weight="600" icon_color="#a8a8a8" margin="20"]

  • Vaginal pain or dryness, not during sex
  • Low sex drive

[/mk_icon_box][vc_row_inner el_id="science-vagPT"][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][mk_toggle title="FOR HEALTH CARE PROVIDERS & THOSE WHO WANT MORE OF THE SCIENCE"]

What is pelvic floor physical therapy? International Society for Sexual Medicine. https://www.issm.info/sexual-health-qa/what-is-pelvic-floor-physical-therapy/

National Vulvodynia Association www.nva.org

[/mk_toggle][vc_row_inner el_id="references-vagPT"][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][mk_toggle title="REFERENCES"]We were unable to find trials of vaginal physical therapy for either vaginal pain or urinary incontinence.[/mk_toggle][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="40"][vc_column_text css=".vc_custom_1617119704921{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]Authors: Dr. Katherine Newton, & Dr. Leslie Snyder.  Last reviewed February 15, 2021[/vc_column_text][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_top="40" margin_bottom="50"][/vc_column][vc_column width="1/3" css=".vc_custom_1594159466278{background-position: center !important;background-repeat: no-repeat !important;background-size: cover !important;}"][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][vc_row_inner][vc_column_inner][mk_fancy_title strip_tags="true" color="#404040" size="20" font_weight="400" margin_bottom="0" font_family="none" align="center"]CREATE MY MENOPLAN[/mk_fancy_title][vc_single_image image="1775" img_size="full" alignment="center" onclick="custom_link" link="http://mymenoplan.org/create-my-menoplan/"][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][/vc_column][/vc_row][vc_row][vc_column][/vc_column][/vc_row]

item.title: VITAMINS
item.dc:creator: katherine
item.content:encoded:
[mk_page_section vertical_align="top" bg_image="http://mymenoplan.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/int-q-as-scaled.jpg" bg_position="left center" bg_stretch="true" sidebar="sidebar-1"][vc_column][mk_fancy_title color="#ffffff" size="56" font_weight="100" margin_top="100" margin_bottom="100" font_family="none" align="center" el_class="eldwin pagetitle"]Treatments[/mk_fancy_title][/vc_column][/mk_page_section][vc_row fullwidth="true"][vc_column][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_color_style="gradient_color" thin_grandient_color_from="#75d8c0" thin_grandient_color_to="#28b590" thin_gradient_color_angle="horizontal" thickness="4" margin_top="0" margin_bottom="0"][/vc_column][/vc_row][vc_row][vc_column][mk_padding_divider][mk_fancy_title strip_tags="true" style="true" color="#4f4b51" size="25" font_weight="400" txt_transform="uppercase" letter_spacing="1" margin_bottom="0" font_family="none" align="center"]vitamins[/mk_fancy_title][mk_padding_divider size="20"][vc_row_inner el_id="what-is-it"][vc_column_inner width="2/3"][vc_column_text disable_pattern="false" css=".vc_custom_1617570565163{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]

  • What is it?
  • Our bottom line: Does it help?

[/vc_column_text][/vc_column_inner][vc_column_inner width="1/3"][vc_single_image image="2128" img_size="full" alignment="center"][vc_column_text el_class="assesments-links" css=".vc_custom_1613676199147{margin: px !important;border-width: px !important;padding: px !important;}"]

[icon name="print" class="" unprefixed_class=""] PRINT PAGE

[/vc_column_text][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][/vc_column][/vc_row][vc_row][vc_column width="2/3"][vc_row_inner el_id="what-vitamins"][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][vc_column_text disable_pattern="false" el_class="#what-is-it" css=".vc_custom_1617570416217{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]WHAT IS IT?

Vitamins are compounds in plant and animal foods that are needed for the body to function normally. The essential vitamins include

Vitamin A, Vitamin C, Vitamin D, Vitamin E, Vitamin K, Vitamin B1 (thiamine), Vitamin B2 (riboflavin), Vitamin B3 (niacin), Vitamin B5 (Pathothenic acid), Vitamin B6, Vitamin B7 (Biotin), Vitamin B9 (folic acid), Vitamin B12[/vc_column_text][vc_row_inner el_id="bottom-vitamins"][vc_column_inner][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][vc_column_text css=".vc_custom_1617570509097{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]OUR BOTTOM LINE:  DOES IT HELP?

NO.

We do not recommend using vitamins to relieve menopausal symptoms.

Though these essential vitamins are important for our health, there is no evidence that they affect menopause symptoms.[/vc_column_text][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="40"][vc_column_text css=".vc_custom_1617119704921{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}"]Authors: Dr. Katherine Newton, & Dr. Leslie Snyder.  Last reviewed February 15, 2021[/vc_column_text][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_top="40" margin_bottom="50"][/vc_column][vc_column width="1/3" css=".vc_custom_1594159466278{background-position: center !important;background-repeat: no-repeat !important;background-size: cover !important;}"][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][vc_row_inner][vc_column_inner][mk_fancy_title strip_tags="true" color="#404040" size="20" font_weight="400" margin_bottom="0" font_family="none" align="center"]CREATE MY MENOPLAN[/mk_fancy_title][vc_single_image image="1775" img_size="full" alignment="center" onclick="custom_link" link="http://mymenoplan.org/create-my-menoplan/"][mk_divider style="thin_solid" thin_single_color="#f2f2f2" thickness="2" margin_bottom="30"][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][/vc_column][/vc_row][vc_row][vc_column][/vc_column][/vc_row]

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: .vc_custom_1617570565163{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}.vc_custom_1613676199147{margin: px !important;border-width: px !important;padding: px !important;}.vc_custom_1594159466278{background-position: center !important;background-repeat: no-repeat !important;background-size: cover !important;}.vc_custom_1617570416217{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}.vc_custom_1617570509097{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}.vc_custom_1617119704921{margin-bottom: 0px !important;}
